QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Prime Minister seen a number of articles in newspapers recently relating to the war in Afghanistan, particularly an article in the Melbourne Age entitled 'Afghans abandoned by their friends'? What good did sanctions such as the boycott of the Olympic Games, the wheat embargoes and the cancellation of the student exchange scholarships do? I ask the Minister whether on 19 February last year he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government sees these measures as the beginning of a long sustained haul. There will be no quick fix to the situation we now face.

Did he also say that, if these things are not done, the lesson which the Soviet Union is allowed to draw is that all it has to do is to sit tight and allow the storm of protest to blow itself out? How does the Minister equate those statements with the Government's decision to lift the wheat embargo against the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and with the Government's general lack of policy and its inaction in relation to the Soviet's continued presence in Afghanistan?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen various articles. I do not recall seeing the one in the Age. I was asked: What good does the Government believe the actions taken by the Government did? The actions taken by the Australian Government, combined with its team work with other governments of the free world, brought to both the United Nations and the whole of the world a strong voice of protest against the USSR, a message that could not have been otherwise conveyed. Undoubtedly the action on the Olympic Games brought more opportunity to say to the Russian people, through the obvious absence of certain delegations to the Games, that significant parts of the world outside were very angry about the action of the Soviet Government in Afghanistan. Generally throughout the world a very strong body of opinion was mobilised against Afghanistan and that, I would put to any reasonable person, was of enormous importance. For example, the Islamic world was mobilised, as never before, in a united view that Afghanistan was not a local thing but an aggression against the Middle East. I would have thought that all those things were of enormous importance. Therefore, I would have thought that the action taken by the Australian Government in common with other governments would merit praise and not criticism.
—Sheer hypocrisy; that is all it is.

—Senator Button says that it is sheer hypocrisy. What he says is that his Labor Party socialist judgment is better than the judgment of virtually all the nations of the free world which believed that the kinds of actions that were being taken ought to have been taken. Of course, as always, the Labor Party in Australia finds itself as the only one in step in the regiment. Let it remain that way.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is it correct that the domestic pilots and engineers awards are due for revision late this year? What action has the Government taken or can it take to ensure that such negotiations are concluded before the due date without crisis conditions, particularly to ensure that the travelling public is not thrown in as the pawns in what many believe will result in an inevitable strike situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with some information on this matter. Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots have finalised negotiations on their pilots award which now has an expiry date of 30 June 1982. The Trans-Australia Airlines award covering pilots expires in June of this year. The Federation has drawn up a log of claims but it has yet to present it to the airlines. That is the information known to me. Negotiations are expected to follow shortly. Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett are joint respondents to a claim served by the Australasian Airline Flight Engineers Association in respect of its award which expired on 31 March. The Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association has served identical logs of claims on Ansett, TAA, East-West Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd in respect of licensed aircraft maintenance engineers whose awards expired on 1 March.

ANSWER.PARA: Preliminary negotiations on the claims are being held in Sydney today. The conclusion of negotiations before the expiry date of awards is not of vital significance to the industry. Negotiations frequently continue beyond the expiry date, with current award provisions continuing while those negotiations proceed. Whilst the industry has a history of direct action in respect of award claims and whilst unforeseen circumstances can arise, we have no grounds at this stage for believing that negotiations between the parties will not be settled satisfactorily. The Government is not a party to award negotiations in the industry, which are conducted within the machinery provisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government does, however, liaise with the parties to ensure that the Government's policies are fully understood and known to all parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, concerns the shipment of live cattle from Australia during the past 12 months. Can the Minister secure for me the total number of live cattle exported for, firstly, slaughter and, secondly, breeding purposes? Can the Minister advise how many meatworks in Australia have closed in the past 18 months?

—I imagine that I can obtain the information sought by the honourable senator. My recollection is that those statistics are available. I should also be able to obtain the statistics on meatworks he has asked for. I am not quite clear from the question as to whether the honourable senator would also be concerned with the seasonal openings and closings of meatworks. He would be familiar with the fact that there are in parts of Australia meatworks which operate for only a defined killing period. I will ask the Minister to give as complete a reply as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his indication that he will get the information for me. Certainly I am referring to those meatworks which have closed; in other words, ceased operation. I am aware of the functions of meatworks.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. It follows from a statement made at Australia's first national energy conference held in Sydney last week which claimed that Australian industry could save $1,000m per annum through the application of energy conservation measures. Can the Minister inform the chamber of the level of demand for oil and other primary energy sources since the introduction of the Government's energy conservation program?

—There is general acceptance throughout the Western world that if all reasonable conservation steps were taken in all forms of energy there could be a saving of energy of between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of currently consumed energy without any damage at all to the living standards of the countries concerned. If that could be achieved, of course, it would be of very great importance. The savings of industrial oil products in Australia have been most encouraging. The import parity pricing policy, which was introduced in August 1978, and the conservation campaign have had very significant gains since that time. Whereas up to 1978 the trend in the consumption of oil was very strongly upwards, there is now a very significant trend downwards. Fuel oil and industrial diesel oil consumption in manufacturing industry is expected to be something like 26 per cent less this year than in 1977-78. That is a very big saving. The total primary energy consumption in manufacturing industry is expected to be only 2 per cent greater than in 1977-78, even though the gross domestic product is expected to have increased by over 10 per cent. In general terms there is a healthy trend towards conservation. That is not to say that we should be complacent. It is necessary to keep up the trends both in conservation and in conversion. There is a very encouraging effect now on exploration and the seeking of alternative fuels. In general terms, what is being said in the Press is attainable and we should all work towards its achievement.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I draw his attention to the Nationwide program of 2 June 1981, of which I have a transcript, concerning standover tactics against small businessmen in the Indooroopilly shopping centre. Is the Minister aware that these standover tactics are taking place and that a major row is looming in Australia over the business practices of shopping centres and the way in which they treat some of their leaseholders? Is it not a fact that the Federal Government's free market forces policy will result in small business people being left at the mercy of landlords?

—For reasons which will be apparent later today, I am not a very avid watcher of Nationwide, so I am not aware of the report to which the honourable senator refers. No one has drawn my attention to what he claims to be standover tactics to be used either at Indooroopilly or at any other shopping centre.
—It was claimed by the people themselves.

—I made it clear that that is a matter which has not been drawn to my attention and that I am not aware of the allegations which have been made by the honourable senator. To a great extent, the matters of trading hours and lease conditions are within the direct competence of State governments and not the Federal Government. It is true that, for example, in the Australian Capital Territory these matters lie within the direct competence of the Federal Government. I will ask the Department of Industry and Commerce to obtain a copy of the matters which have been raised by the honourable senator and to draw them to the attention of the Minister to see whether they have any relevance to the jurisdiction which we exercise in this Territory.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The words 'being left at the mercy of landlords' were contained in a letter which the Minister received from a person in the Australian Capital Territory, in a complaint against the Government's intention to deregulate shop trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, which clearly is within the competence of the Federal Government.
—I do not read all of the correspondence received by the Minister for Industry and Commerce.
—You are representing him here. It is addressed to you.

—I do not read all of the correspondence received by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Any honourable senator would know that. However, I will draw the contents of the question to the Minister's attention. As I indicated in my reply, this is a matter which is within the jurisdiction of the Federal Government within the Australian Capital Territory, not elsewhere in Australia. The original question, I thought, raised matters relating to Indooroopilly, which I understand to be a suburb of Brisbane, and raised matters which go well beyond the direct responsibility of this Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Further to my question yesterday about the need to maintain an adequate telephone system because of the needs of special groups in the community including invalids, those who provide emergency services and hospitals, I ask: Can the Minister provide further information on the extent of the telephone dislocation and the problems that this dislocation is causing in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson, being a Tasmanian senator, would be particularly concerned with the capacity of his State to maintain its communications not only within Tasmania but also with the mainland. I understand that some work bans were imposed for two days this week and that, during two days of negotiations, no further bans were applied. I understand that the situation at present is that negotiations are in some difficulties. I am not certain whether further bans are to be applied in the next day or so. Considerable difficulties have been encountered throughout Australia. I am informed that a coaxial cable failure occurred between Toowoomba and Pittsworth and that that has resulted in severe subscriber trunk dialling congestion on the eastern seaboard, in particular on the Melbourne-Brisbane route. That is not going to help those who are involved in the commercial life of that area, those who are trying to communicate between families or those who need communications for any other reasons. There has been a breakdown in the Sydney-Canberra route, resulting in significant STD congestion between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. A Sydney-Tamworth radio bearer has failed. That has resulted in congestion in the Tamworth, New- castle and Armidale areas as well as affecting international traffic by limiting Overseas Telecommunications Commission circuits to Moree. I am sure that all honourable senators will be alarmed to know that earlier this week all direct circuits to Goondiwindi were out of order. Goondiwindi was cut off.

ANSWER.PARA: On a more serious note, any honourable senator who has read this morning's Sydney Morning Herald will have noticed a report on the front page that yesterday a major fault occurred in the trunk exchange at Haymarket and that disrupted Sydney's STD networks. Against the background of my comments earlier this week that the union was trying to allow for life and limb situations, I also draw attention to the fact that it is reported in this morning's newspapers that the fault at the Haymarket exchange is affecting the emergency number 000 in Sydney. This is a most serious matter for people who use this number for precisely the kind of life and limb situations which were thought to be protected. The Government's concern is that the people of Australia should be able to use communication facilities for legitimate purposes. We are concerned at the extent of the breakdowns that have occurred. The Government is continuing to monitor the situation and to try to ensure that these breakdowns are kept to a minimum.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It concerns the status of land under claim by Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. Is such land still protected from dealings or usage which would in any way prejudice its future use as Aboriginal land as agreed according to the Woodward recommendations when the Everingham Government took over the Northern Territory from the Commonwealth Government? I refer specifically to the area of the Lake Amadeus land claim near Ayers Rock. Is the Minister aware of any recent granting of a lease or rights to a lease over any part of the Lake Amadeus land claim?

—There are a number of issues relating to land under claim which are presently the subject of consultation among the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and the three land councils in the Northern Territory. As honourable senators will be aware, these three groups have been meeting for some months to try to develop a series of agreed positions in relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory. One of the issues has been the status of land under claim particularly as it applies to applications for mining exploration licences and other matters of this kind. The matter is unresolved at present. The negotiations, which have been tripartite and constructive and have been designed to try to reach an agreed position, are continuing. I am not aware of the particular Lake Amadeus situation to which Senator Ryan referred. I would appreciate it if she would make this information known to me so that I can follow it up. If there are particular issues involved and if they could affect the standing or the status of the Aboriginal claimants, I would want to have that information available to me. I would be grateful if the honourable senator could let me have that material.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. Is there any health hazard to members of the Parliament and the occupants of Parliament House from the tent dwellers over the road? How are they providing for their sewage and waste disposal? Why are they entitled to camp there when a similar right was denied to Aboriginals in recent times? Finally, what is the member for Canberra in another place doing about this matter?

—Perhaps this question would be better addressed to the Minister for Health as he may have some information on it. Whilst nobody denies people the right to demonstrate properly in all circumstances, the fact is that there must be a collection of rubbish and other material in the area of the tent site opposite Parliament House which may create some health hazard. I will ask the Minister to look at the matter on behalf of Senator MacGibbon and make sure that every effort possible is being made to ensure that that is being cleaned up. The other matters about which the honourable senator asked are matters of very real concern as well. It would be the Government's intention, I think, to ensure that people have the right of access to Parliament House and have the right to demonstrate and make their point in a proper way. Certainly the Government will investigate the matter further. I think that I had better bring down a report later for Senator MacGibbon.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that, because of the shortage of available repatriation boards in New South Wales, a number of the applications for war widows' pensions that have been lodged in my State have had to be sent to Western Australia for determination? Has this process been holding up consideration of applications for war widows' pensions in New South Wales? Why is it that boards are not available to handle the work in New South Wales? Will the Minister take early action to see that the position is rectified?

—Senator Douglas McClelland has asked a question which is a source of real concern not only to New South Wales but also to all other States. There are considerable difficulties in having appeals and assessments handled by the repatriation system as quickly as we would all like. It is a function of the nature of the system that there are some difficulties. I am not particularly aware that the situation in New South Wales is worse than that in any other State but I will make inquiries for Senator McClelland in respect of that. As to the broader matter of what the Government might be doing, I am taking a very real interest in the problems of the appeals structure of the repatriation system and will bring down recommendations in this matter for the Government to consider in conjunction with the ex-service organisations.
—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the basis of one senator from the premier State to another.
—You were not too premier last Tuesday night.

—I could answer that interjection but I will not. Is the Minister prepared to emulate the words of Marshal Petain in Paris in World War I when he said about the German armies: 'They shall not pass'? Would the Minister say that on behalf of the people of Sydney to the airlines about this attempt to fudge on the curfew which could be imposed on the people of Sydney? Will he say to the airlines: 'They shall not pass. No breaking of the curfew'?

—Marshal Petain did say 'They shall not pass', but he was not always in a position to enforce that. It so happens that the Commonwealth Government is in a position to say 'On ne passerez jamais', and we will ensure that the law as it is is maintained.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and concerns the important prawn fishing industry in South Australia. I am sure all honourable senators have enjoyed some sampling of South Australian prawns. The prawn industry in South Australia, I remind honourable senators, is divided into two parts-that in State waters and that in Commonwealth waters. The St Vincent Gulf Prawn Boat Owners Association represents that part of the industry which is in State waters and which is threatened, the Association alleges, by the fishermen taking the prawns in the Commonwealth waters. As a result, the South Australian Government, the State Department of Fisheries, the South Australian branch of the Australian Fisheries Council and the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, it is alleged, all seek some restriction on, if not the complete closing of the prawn industry in Commonwealth waters. I wonder whether the Minister has responded to this request.

—The niceties of Commonwealth-State demarcations seem to be totally lost on prawns and this gives rise to very severe difficulties in regulating this matter satisfactorily without there being broad agreement as to a set of rules that the prawns will know will apply whether within territorial waters or without. I am not familiar with the particular problem. I had rather hoped that I might be asked something about prawning in northern waters, with which I am more familiar, but I will make inquiries of the Minister for Primary Industry to see whether the problem that the honourable senator raised has been dealt with satisfactorily.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. There are no histrionics in the question any more than there were histrionics in the question yesterday. Yesterday and on previous occasions, he cited an Australian Financial Review report to support claims that he had expressed appropriate reservations about Rundle's prospects. Was he referring to a report headed 'Carrick's Rundle doubts' in the Australian Financial Review of 5 March 1980? If so, did a member of his staff complain to the Australian Financial Review that the story was misleading because its interpretation of his remarks was unduly pessimistic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the matters that I was referring to in support of the fact that I made many statements in public and in this Parliament regarding the problems of Rundle and the enormous difficulties-engineering and financial-would have been the one that Senator Walsh quoted. I do not know of any intervention by any member of my staff at all and I do not recollect any discussion between me and any member of my staff. I do know that when I read that article I felt it did not totally reflect what I had said. I have been careful-believe it or not-to give neither an over-optimistic view nor an over-pessimistic view of any project. It seems to me that my job is not to influence the market in any way except to ensure when evidence comes to me that what may be the public perception is based upon the reasonable facts that are available.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a feeling that in a casual conversation which I had with an employee of the Australian Financial Review I said in a whimsical way some weeks later, but that may be wrong, that a more extreme interpretation had been taken than I had intended, but it is in the mists of time. I am not aware of any member of my staff doing so. I do not recollect that I would have suggested that they do so. In fact, I do not employ a Press officer to contact the Press. If there is contact apart from the ordinary hand-outs, I do it myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister checked with his staff? If not, will he?

—I have not checked with my staff. I take it that if any one had been in contact it would have been my previous principal private secretary who is no longer with me. If it is regarded as a matter of importance, I will do so. Let me simply say that the answer I have just given is based on the best of my knowledge and belief and it is not my normal practice to ask my staff to correct information in the Press. If information is substantially wrong, it is my normal practice to endeavour to do something about it myself.

—I too am having trouble with the northern prawns. They do not seem to understand the difference between Commonwealth and Territory legislation. Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry advise the number of prawning trawlers operating around Australia's northern coast and the controls in operation restricting the numbers of licensed trawlers and the amount of their catch? Is it correct that prawn harvests are decreasing? Is it considered that the areas are being over-trawled? If this is so, can the Minister indicate what action the Government will take to restrict the number of licensed trawlers to ease the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second question this morning on the prawn industry. I am more pleased to get this one because I have some information from the Minister on the position in the north. This year 604 vessels were engaged in prawn trawling in Commonwealth waters in northern Australia; that is, extending from Cape Londonderry in Western Australia to Bowen in Queensland. Of that number, 277 vessels operated on the limited entry northern prawn fishery from Cape Ford in the Northern Territory to Cape York in Queensland. There are, of course, concerns about the possibility of overfishing in this industry. Two principal management controls are imposed in the northern prawn fishery, namely, a limitation on the entry of vessels to that fishery and seasonal closures for a 12-week period to 15 March in two specified areas of the fishery. These areas are Fog Bay and waters in the south-eastern sector of the Gulf of Carpentaria.

ANSWER.PARA: Outside the northern prawn fishery there are no restrictions on prawn fishing around the northern coast. The fact is that prawn catches can fluctuate widely. The catches from the prawn trawlers in northern Australia have varied between 4,900 tonnes and 13,000 tonnes in recent years. The 1980 catch of 11,600 tonnes was the third highest on record. In 1979, 12,900 tonnes were landed and the record catch of 13,000 tonnes was landed in 1975. Recent catches have been at high levels. I am advised that banana prawns in the Gulf of Carpentaria are heavily fished. However, there is no evidence available to indicate that this or other species are jeopardised by the current level of fishing effort. The management of these fisheries is under continual review by the Commonwealth-State fisheries management committee which comes under the general direction of the Australian Fisheries Council. Additionally, the Queensland Government has limited the number of prawn trawlers operating in territorial waters off the Queensland east coast.

The only other thing I wish to say is that many honourable senators this week have had the opportunity of talking with ex-Senator Glenister Sheil. Those who did so and discussed the prawn fishing industry might have been very relieved to know that prawn fishing or prawn farming as a commercial venture is being developed in the Pacific area. A very small number of female prawns can be used to produce quite vast numbers of prawns. Those who are addicted to the night of the long prawn, which seems to be a feature of the operation of this Parliament, might be relieved to know that, notwithstanding the very substantial natural supplies of prawns which are available, it does appear that these in the future will be augmented by very substantial numbers of farm prawns.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Durack in his capacity both as Attorney-General and as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Now that the Attorney-General has acquired something of a reputation as a great law reformer in the Murphy tradition, will he consider adding further lustre to that reputation by expediting some long awaited amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act? I refer to those provisions which determine citizenship by reference to the person who is the 'responsible parent' and which are based on the thoroughly sexist assumption that it is the father who is the responsible parent in most circumstances. The Attorney will no doubt be aware that practical problems continue to arise in this area and that promises have been made by a number of successive Immigration Ministers to review and overhaul those provisions, but nothing ever seems actually to happen. Can the Attorney-General maintain the fine progressive standards he has set with the Acts Interpretation Act legislation in the last week or two and succeed where others have failed?

—It is well known that Senator Evans believes that reforms of the law are law reform only if he agrees with them. Of course, quite a number of reforms and changes in the law of some magnitude have been introduced by myself and my colleagues in government over recent years to maintain the tradition we have established. I am happy to refer the question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I may even have the opportunity of taking some interest in the matter myself.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security noted an item in today's Sydney Morning Herald under the title 'State houses empty despite mounting need'? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: That is the New South Wales Government-
professed commitment to low-cost housing needs the report's recommendations have not been acted upon.
Though the still confidential task force list is therefore incomplete, the conclusion of the report is that at least 413 dwellings are standing either vacant or seen as surplus to departmental needs.
The report concludes 'that there appears to be more than sufficient government-owned residential properties to make the emergency accommodation unit viable'.
Can the Minister inform the Senate whether his Department has already discussed this problem with the New South Wales Government departments and, if not, whether it intends to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, but my attention was drawn to the article during Question Time. Honourable senators will be aware that in the past the provision of emergency housing in general has been a matter of State concern and State jurisdiction, although the Commonwealth has been involved in the provision of some assistance in regard to night shelters, and has assisted organisations to provide accommodation for the chronically homeless. That is an important area of Commonwealth activity. The field of emergency housing generally has been largely in the hands of the States and particular responsibilities have been borne by State housing authorities in most parts of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I am interested to hear of the figures mentioned in the article. In one sense I hope that they are correct because if it is true that in New South Wales empty government-owned housing is available it should be true, as was indicated by the honourable senator in another reference to what was said in the article, that provision can be made for the emergency accommodation needs of New South Wales citizens. One might ask what that has to do with the Commonwealth Government. It does have something to do with it because, at the last elections, we indicated that we were interested in discussing with the States new policy developments in the field of emergency accommodation for families. Within the last week or two, and in the context of the questions which have arisen about women's refuges, the Prime Minister has written to the State Premiers indicating that the States may expect to hear from me with respect to the Commonwealth's interest in the area of emergency accommodation for families. Therefore, it is a matter of interest to me that there may already be available within the State of New South Wales resources that can be utilised for that purpose.

I believe that there is a good deal of goodwill in Australia, and indeed in this chamber, towards those Australians who for one reason or another are in need of emergency accommodation. I believe that it is an area in which a co-operative effort between the Commonwealth and the States may succeed in ensuring that the needs of these people are better met in the future than they have been in the past. I say that while acknowledging the premier role which the States have played in this area and without in any way wishing to suggest that the Commonwealth would want to take over the very substantial responsibilities which have been exercised by the States, very often to the considerable satisfaction of their citizens.

What amount of money has been offered to the Victorian Government as a special payment for administration of the aids for disabled persons scheme? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: POTATO MARKETING: AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Miniter representing the Minister for Primary Industry, refers to the dangers of transnational companies exploiting the generally welcome moves for closer economic relations with New Zealand. Will the Government ensure that any agreement with New Zealand for closer economic relations involves action concerning the possibility that transnational potato processing and potato product manufacturers may use the highly subsidised New Zealand potato to allow alternate production as between New Zealand and Australian factories, by the same group of companies, in order to exploit potato growers in both countries by engineering an artificial price war between them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Commonwealth has, in recent years, been pursuing the matter of closer economic relations with New Zealand. I think they will be aware that within the last few weeks the Deputy Prime Minister has again visited New Zealand and had talks which, I think, he described as being generally satisfactory over a range of issues of concern to both countries. The honourable senator in his question raised the particular concerns of potato growers who fall within a group which has been concerned about the implications of what is happening. As a result of that concern there has been a series of meetings which have involved representatives of those particular industries, both among themselves and with government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that a special meeting of the Australian Horticultural Growers Council was held in January last and a working party was formed to analyse the implications. The working party met with officials in March and, following that, the Department of Primary Industry prepared detailed background information papers for the working party. I am advised that the Australian Horticultural Growers Council delegates met with the Minister on 29 April to put their views on closer economic relations. I am further advised that, with the exception of the potato growers of Australia, industry representation on the Council supports freer trade with New Zealand in horticultural products, subject to certain safeguards and conditions. The potato growers of Australia oppose the inclusion of potatoes in the closer economic relationship with New Zealand, on the basis that low priced New Zealand imports would cause serious disruption to the local industry. I think that is in line with the sorts of concerns which have been expressed by the honourable senator this morning.

The Prime Minister has given an assurance that the details of any proposed new arrangements emerging from studies and consultations associated with this issue will be made public before substantive decisions are taken by the Government. The Government has also given an assurance, through the Minister for Primary Industry, that the Government is committed to full consultation with the States and the industries involved before any decisions are taken. Obviously, the matters which are of concern to the honourable senator and which he has raised in this question are matters which are squarely before the Government. Clearly they will be taken into account very carefully before any decisions are taken inimical to the potato growers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Transport will recall that in early April, following the Holcroft inquiry, the Minister for Transport promised that in relation to Melbourne-Tasmania air routes the Government would set a maximum air fare at 90 per cent of the fare that would otherwise prevail if the full Holcroft-type formula were implemented. Further, as at the same time the Minister estimated the cost of this filling of the revenue gap to airlines at some $5m per annum, is the Government's commitment limited indeed to $5m per annum or will the Government always fill the revenue gap caused to operators by the Government's insistence that only 90 per cent of the otherwise prevailing fare should be charged?
—I do not have the information which Senator Tate seeks on this matter. I will need to refer the question to the Minister to obtain a reply for him.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he is aware that the South Australian Government has proclaimed the Chiropractors Act which came into effect on 27 April this year? I understand that the Government has provided for a three-month period of grace during which time applications for the registration of chiropractors will be considered. Has Mrs Adamson, the South Australian Minister of Health, contacted Mr MacKellar with respect to a Commonwealth review of the benefits situation of patients receiving chiropractic treatment? Can the Minister also say whether other States have introduced similar legislation or are contemplating taking such action? Will the Government encourage the States to introduce legislation similar to South Australia's legislation so that patients who choose to take advantage of this treatment can be recognised by the Commonwealth Government and by the health funds under the National Health Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of the registration of chiropractors has been running in various States for some time. The question that governments have to consider is where the major benefit to its citizens lies. The word 'chiropractic' covers a whole range of disciplines, some of which require formal training and some of which require much less rigorous training. It is generally felt that, without a registration scheme, some people, believing that they are attending a chiropractor who has training, may in fact be attending a less trained person. That is in no way to offer any comment upon the appropriateness or otherwise of the philosophy or theory upon which such training is based. I believe some States have already gone some way towards registering chiropractors who have adequate amounts of training. I think New South Wales has already taken this step and South Australia has followed. If that means that people will know that a person who is registered has an appropriately approved level of training, it will be of benefit to the citizens of the State.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a problem with chiropractic in Australia, as the honourable senator will know. There are two major streams of graduates who come from two major training areas, one being the United States school of training and the other being a school in Australia. They do not seem to get on very well. They do not seem to talk very much to each other. The battle they have been having has tended to make more difficult the kinds of negotiations that would go with registration. The honourable senator will also be aware that this has spilled over into the appropriate support for training schemes for chiropractors. I am not aware whether Mrs Adamson has made representations to my colleague the Minister for Health.

The question which the honourable senator raised as to whether there should by Commonwealth rebates for chiropractic and, if so, how they should be structured and to whom they should be available is another area entirely. Again, one has to ask about benefits to patients. Such a decision would have to be taken in a general Budget context. The Senate will be aware that only a few years ago the Commonwealth extended its coverage to pick up optometrists. Senator Jessop would have an expert knowledge of that matter. That was a major extension, as it were, of the medical benefit rebate principle. To extend medical benefit rebates to chiropractic would involve another major policy decision and I think that the Government has yet to address itself to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's attack on the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on Thursday, 21 May, in respect of wage fixing principles. As the Government is of the view that wage fixing principles are necessary to bring about stability, would the Minister not agree that price control is also a necessary part of the equation to bring about stability in the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall the nature of the Prime Minister's statements concerning the President of the ACTU on the particular day, but the Prime Minister, in common with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, is keen to see adopted wage fixing principles which will provide two things: First of all, sufficient wage restraint to keep inflation down and, therefore, to make the purchasing power of real wages stable and to give an opportunity to the people of Australia to enjoy the standard of living we have; and, secondly, avoidance of over-award or hours breaches which will drive up inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of the cost of living and price fixing, if Senator McIntosh knows history he will know that doctrinaire price control has failed wherever it has been imposed. Where price control has been imposed, it has created corruption, has generally made the maximum price the minimum price and has forced up prices. Senator McIntosh would be aware that, when the Commission determines wages, it takes into account the consumer price index and, therefore, there is a direct relationship between prices and the wages fixed. Overall it is the Government's desire that the people of Australia should increase their capacity to share in higher living standards. By doing that, they must, of course, all take part in a restraint which will keep costs down so that we can continue now to hold the restoration of our trading pattern with other countries which gives us our capacity to expand our social welfare and other facilities.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Education to the announcement made by the Prime Minister, when outlining the results of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that the Government does not see a need to establish a university in the Northern Territory. Did members of the Tertiary Education Commission travel to Darwin just prior to the Prime Minister's announcement to make an on-the-spot assessment of a proposed Northern Territory university? Did those members travel at great cost by charter aircraft? If so, do these factors indicate that the Tertiary Education Commission-or even the Chairman of that Commission-was not consulted in relation to the Government's decision not to proceed with a university in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any travel to Darwin in recent times by private charter or other means by members of the Tertiary Education Commission; nor am I aware, if they did travel to Darwin, for what purpose they did so. I am aware that, during the four years I was Minister for Education, the Tertiary Education Commission took a very keen interest in the development of tertiary education in the Northern Territory both as to the Darwin college and as to the ancillary development in Alice Springs. I am aware that the Tertiary Education Commission had a very real understanding of the difficulties of creating tertiary institutions of very high quality and offering a range of choice in such a huge area with such a sparse population. My recollection is that in that time the Tertiary Education Commission was certainly not contemplating any suggestion that on top of the Darwin college there should be superimposed an additional body, a university. That is my clear recollection. The aim of the Tertiary Education Commission and of the then Minister-me-was to ensure that the college would be so developed that it could provide, both in excellence and in choice, a range of disciplines to meet the demands of the people.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the great difficulties with setting up a new institution in areas of sparse population is, first of all, that it may well not attract academic staff of a high calibre and that it may have such a small population that it would have a handful of faculties which would in fact cannibalise the existing institutions and draw away from them. I hesitate to enter into the reasons which might have been in the minds of the Tertiary Education Commission. I am not aware of any recent view of the Commission. I imagine that what the Government has done would be in line with the Commission's view. It is certainly in line with its previous views. Lest that has any inaccuracies, I will seek out the information from the Minister for Education and let the honourable senator know.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 3 June, Senator Sibraa asked a question about Kampuchea. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to that question from Senator Sibraa:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the reports to which the honourable senator has referred. As far as Mr Rajaratnam's remarks are concerned, I was somewhat surprised that Mr Rajaratnam wrote in the way he did in the light of my visit to Singapore next weekend. I look forward to a friendly and frank discussion with Singapore leaders then about the Kampuchean situation.

In regard to Australian policy towards the Democratic Kampuchea regime, on 14 February last year Australia withdrew its recognition of that regime. We now recognise no regime in Kampuchea. Consistent with this fact, and in the course of answering incorrect assertions in a newspaper article that morning, on 28 May I said that there had been the possibility of a vote on Democratic Kampuchea credentials at the World Health Assembly which was held in Geneva earlier in May, and that, had a vote been taken, Australia would have abstained. In the event a vote was not taken.
So far as any future votes are concerned, we will consider our position in the light of circumstances at the time.

So there can be no misunderstanding, I wish to make clear that this decision in no way lessens our opposition to the Heng Samrin regime which is kept in power only by the Vietnamese army which installed it. We will not recognise that regime. The Government continues to support the efforts of the ASEAN countries in accordance with resolution 35/6 of the United Nations General Assembly, and looks forward to participating in the international conference on Kampuchea to be held in New York next month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. On 6 March 1980 the Australian Broadcasting Commission television program Nationwide reported on a number of elections in the State seat of Kimberley in Western Australia. At the time of the Nationwide report I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In the course of the report reference was made to one of my brothers, John Chaney, and to the fact that he is my brother. It was suggested that he had taken action during the 1977 election at the Turkey Creek polling station with the intention and effect of depriving Aboriginal voters of their vote. By association with that allegation, reflections were also cast on me as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Subsequent to that report in Nationwide the matter was referred to in Parliament on a number of occasions. On 1 April 1980 it was referred to in the Senate by Senator Walsh. As I indicated to the Senate on 1 April 1980:

SPEECH.PARA: From a personal point of view, the reflections on me and on my brother for his part in the 1977 election, reflect the difficulty of being involved at all in this field-
I referred there to the field of Aboriginal affairs-
without attracting odium. I regret that the views which were expressed with respect to my brother were expressed in this debate.
I went on to say:
I do not intend to answer them now but maybe I will do so at some more appropriate time later.
On 16 May 1980 in the Senate Senator Robertson referred to the Kimberley election and stated:

It is understandable that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney) is sensitive about this area. He is sensitive because he is a member of the Liberal Party of Australia and because the Western Australian Liberal Party took the shameful action against the people of the north-west. He is sensitive because his own brother was involved in this matter. I do not like to raise these personal matters but . . .

Once again, I made no reply at the time but I think honourable senators would know that I would have found that reference objectionable. It is also true that the matter was referred to in the House of Representatives prior to the Nationwide report on 27 February 1980. Mr Dawkins said:

. . . the brother of the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney) who engaged in a plot to deprive Aborigines in the Kimberley of exercising their right to vote in the State election at that time.

It is a pity that neither the ABC nor any of those who raised this matter in the Parliament took the trouble to check the public record in this matter. The facts relating to my brother were readily ascertainable in the record of the Court of Disputed Returns. Neither I nor my brother could take action for what was said in this place or in the House of Representatives. My brother did, however, take appropriate action against the Australian Broadcasting Commission and that action has now been settled on the basis that the Commission pay him damages for the defamation. The apology which I now intend to read was read on Nationwide last week and has been published in the Australian and the Age newspapers. The apology reads:

On the 6th March 1980 Nationwide carried a report from Andrew Olle concerning the recent Western Australian State elections. In particular it dealt with the supply of a 44-gallon drum of port to Aborigines at Turkey Creek in the Kimberley region.

During that report reference was made to the previous State election in 1977, and to the subsequent decision of a Court of Disputed Returns upsetting the result of the election in the Kimberley electorate. It was suggested that a Liberal Party scrutineer at the Turkey Creek polling station had insisted upon the use of technical provisions of the Electoral Act with the intention, and effect, of depriving Aboriginal voters of their vote. The scrutineer referred to was Mr John Chaney, the brother of Senator Fred Chaney, who was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at the time of the report.

Any such suggestion is entirely without foundation. In his decision in the Court of Disputed Returns His Honour Mr Justice Smith, having heard evidence from Mr John Chaney and others present during voting at Turkey Creek in 1977 said that there was no evidence that the actions of (scrutineers) played any significant part' in the informal votes cast. The Court found that there was nothing improper whatsoever in the actions of Mr Chaney who was in fact only at the polling place for about half an hour. During that time only 5 or 6 votes were cast out of a total poll of 69 for the day. Neither at Turkey Creek nor anywhere else did Mr Chaney use or seek to use any technical provisions of the Electoral Act.

Nationwide unreservedly withdrew any suggestion that Mr Chaney's actions in the 1977 Western Australian State Election were in any way improper and apologises to him for the concern and embarrassment caused to him by its report.
I too express regret that the fact that he was my brother brought him to public attention. I am pleased that the apology has now been published by the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I refer to the statement which has been made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I think it is more appropriate that I bring down a statement on this matter perhaps next week by way of personal explanation. I think, without pre-empting what I will say, that we will talk about previous elections rather than the one referred to.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. I am at a disadvantage in not having the Hansard to which Senator Chaney has just referred and therefore I do not know precisely what I said last year, but from--
—That is not a bit unusual.

—Will you be quiet, harpy? From my recollections, I made it clear that Senator Chaney had in fact disobeyed the instructions given to him by the Liberal Party of Western Australia. I said that he was involved in the matter, as he was. He went so far and then decided to pull out. I think it is to his credit that he did decide to pull out and ultimately, of course, to spill the beans on the rest of the Liberal Party. The fact remains, however, that a plan was devised by the Liberal Party of Western Australia at the highest levels, the clear intention of which was to prevent Aboriginals from exercising their right to vote. Although Senator Chaney's brother can be commended for the fact that, having originally co-operated, he then pulled out and in effect mutinied on the Liberal Party, Senator Chaney and, as far as I know his brother, are both still members of the Liberal Party and cannot entirely shed the responsibility for the actions which that party took on that occasion.

—by leave-Once again, no doubt inadvertently, there is confusion in what the honourable senator has said in terms of whom he is referring to. He has referred to me when clearly he meant to refer to my brother. If he checks the Hansard pinks, he will find a reference to Senator Chaney when presumably he was referring to my brother. I am sorry that the matter has given rise to further debate but the fact is that it has been raised on three occasions in this Parliament. I thought it appropriate to record the position and the fact that when the same allegation was made outside the chamber it gave rise to an action for damages and an apology. That is a matter relevant to this Parliament.
—I wish to make a personal explanation. As I understand it, in Western Australia truth is not necessarily defence against action for defamation.
—That is not a personal explanation.
