DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's excessively stringent financial restrictions on the Australian Broadcasting Commission which threaten the Commission's future ability to comply with its charter.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's Canberra Times there is an article commenting on the current plight of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, a once great and still good broadcasting service. In the course of that article the author sets out a current program for ABC television as he sees it after the cuts foreshadowed by the Government come into effect. The program reads like this:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.30 Epilogue (repeat) PGR
7.00 Test Pattern
8.00 Transylvanian Clog Dancing Competition (B & W) (1934, repeat)
9.30 Play School: With Richard Carleton.
10.00 Test Pattern (Repeat)
Noon: Travel Talk: ABC staff screen their slides and discuss their favourite holiday places.
1.00 Talbot Duckmanton Show (melodrama)
2.00: Best of the Test Patterns (AO)
3.00: Mr Squiggle, Clive Hale and Friends
4.00: Test Patterns from Around the World: Introduced by Bill Peach
5.00: English for Ethnics: With Molly Meldrum
6.00: Monkey (cheap Japanese rubbish)
7.00: National News (Courtesy of Channels 7, 9 and 10)

So the program goes on. That would normally be funny. In fact, I suppose it is funny. The Australian Broadcasting Commission has been a great innovative broadcasting organisation and a real alternative to the predominantly commercial media in Australia. Through the arts, through music, through the spoken word, through journalism and through creative film, it has set a pattern for broadcasting and television in Australia. The public affairs programs now succeeding on commercial television had their origins in the pioneering efforts of the ABC. The same can be said about news programs and drama programs.

That great organisation is now fighting for its life. The Government has so wound down the Australian Broadcasting Commission's activities that it will be very difficult to wind it up again. If the infrastructure of an organisation like the ABC is destroyed or is allowed to become completely outdated or outmoded, it is a very difficult and a very expensive thing to restore it to its proper condition. There have been savage reductions in the amounts which the Australian Broadcasting Commission can spend on programs and there are no other ways in which costs can be reduced. The Australian Broadcasting Commission management has, in a sense, betrayed the creative people who made the reputation of the ABC. The ABC has committed itself, for example, to spend $2m on cricket-$2m which will go to rights to broadcast the cricket through satellites and circuits. That $2m is not, in my view, a necessary item of expenditure. It is a result of ABC management's obsessions with its successes of the past. The obsession to take on the Packer television interests led management and the Commissioners of the ABC to squander $2m on cricket coverage that Packer would have taken with no cost to the public. When stringency was needed, that sort of money should not have been spent on coverage of the cricket.

This week the Dix inquiry will be reporting to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I hope it will give advice on the way in which the Commission has been managed in the past and how it ought to be managed in the future. There is an important reason for seeking an early debate in this Parliament on the recommendations of the Dix Committee. The members of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, headed by Mr Norgard, were hand-picked by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I say that without fear of contradiction. The last Minister responsible for communications, Mr Staley, suggested names of some very distinguished and objectively minded Australians for the positions of commissioners of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. All his recommendations in relation to these people were overruled by the Prime Minister. Instead, we have a Commission now presided over by a man who made his name as the chairman of a pipeline authority-singularly inappropriate experience, one would have thought, for a national broadcasting service appointment.

The Prime Minister has imposed his standards on the national broadcasting network by the appointments which have been made to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Commission's management failures are, in a sense, his. The present members of the Commission are so dreary, stale, flat and unprofitable that David Williamson, the great Australian playwright, could not tolerate being on the Commission and, after nine months, resigned. The sins of this dreary management should not, at this point, be visited on the employees of the ABC who have given it its high public standing or on its loyal viewers and listeners.

Let us look at what the Government has done to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. In five years under the Fraser Government, the allocation to the ABC has gone down by 22 per cent in real terms. That is revealed in the last report to the Parliament by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The ABC has recently been told by the Department of Finance that a further cut of more than 10 per cent in real terms will occur in the next financial year. Since the Fraser Government came to power--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is speculation.

—I said that the Australian Broadcasting Commission has been told by the Department of Finance that there will be a further cut in the coming year. The staff numbers of the Australian Broadcasting Commission have been cut by 1,400-20 per cent-in five years of Fraser Government. As a result the ABC spends more money engaging people in contract employment than it would if some sections of the staff were still there. Because of the razor gang's report it has had to reduce staff numbers by another 2 per cent, representing a loss of another 130 jobs. Of course, more jobs will go. The ABC has been told to cover comprehensively the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne in September and the Commonwealth Games, which will require additional people. This will impose additional strains on the resources of the ABC. The Government has told the ABC that it must act as host broadcaster for CHOGM. Added cost in providing editing suites and other expensive facilities for visiting television and radio journalists will result.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as the razor gang's cuts, there is also to be a 3 per cent cut in non-salary expenditure. This message has been conveyed to the ABC by the Department of Finance. So other departments and statutory authorities can probably anticipate losing 3 per cent of their non-salary expenditure in the August Budget. The Department of Finance has assumed that the ABC should earn about $10m next financial year, the same as this year. That income normally would come from selling publications based on ABC programs. But last year's result was up by about $700,000 because of the sale of the program The Timeless Land. There will be no The Timeless Land this year because there will not be enough money for that sort of program and consequently there will be no increase in the ABC's revenue. Because of the Government's parsimony, the ABC has been carrying over unpaid bills year after year since 1975. This now amounts to $7m. This has been done with the connivance of the Department of Finance in Canberra. The ABC is now carrying debts to the extent of $7m which have accumulated over the last few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debts to whom?
—All sorts of creditors-rolling debts.
—Commercial people?

—Yes-rolling debts. This has been done with the connivance of the Department of Finance. During the next financial year, again with the connivance of the Department of Finance, the ABC plans to reduce its debts by $1.5m. That will not now be possible because the debt obviously will continue to grow. That is a scandal of enormous proportions in relation to a national broadcasting organisation such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The fact is that as a result of this process it has been getting further and further into debt.

SPEECH.PARA: One directive from Canberra underlines the Fraser Government's ideology and also its idiocy. The ABC leases premises at 165 William Street, Sydney. That is the head office of the ABC news services amongst other things. The Department of Administrative Services decided recently that that lease should cease. The ABC has been directed to move from those premises. The cost of that move will be $600,000. The ABC is not being provided with $600,000 to make that move. It certainly will not have that sort of money after July of this year if the present proposals are allowed to go ahead. More recently, the extraordinarily incompetent razor gang-the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee-decided that the ABC should rationalise its accommodation. For years now the Australian Broadcasting Commission has been asking the Fraser Government to concentrate its building operations in fewer buildings than the 24 in Sydney alone which it rents, to save some money and increase efficiency.

In the last report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission attention was again drawn to the desire of the ABC to rationalise its building program. When the razor gang report came down one of its recommendations was that the ABC should rationalise its building program. The ridiculous muddle-headed nature of this recommendation can be seen from the fact that the razor gang was totally ignorant of ABC requests over three years. Unfortunately, as I said earlier, the commissioners of the ABC have been hand picked by the Prime Minister and share, predominantly, the Government's views. Yet even they are now crying out 'this is enough'. I hope they will have the same sort of success as the former chairman of commissioners-I refer to Sir Henry Bland of long memory and short duration in his role-who also had to cry out that the ABC, as he put it in 1976, had been 'cut to the bone'. That is what Sir Henry Bland, the tough bureaucrat, said about the ABC in 1976. In every year since 1976 the ABC budget has been cut further and further. The commissioners have pointed out continually in their reports that the ABC is losing its capacity to compete with the commercial networks. The ABC, in its last annual report stated:

The ABC is now in a relatively worse financial position than it was five years ago, while the commercial broadcasting organisations are considerably stronger than they were and are looking forward to significant further expansion.

The report went on to state that that expansion was arising from increased advertising revenue. Yet in this Parliament on this date in June 1981 when these cuts are foreshadowed for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, a national broadcasting service which is respected by 80 per cent of the population for the integrity of its news bulletins, when its plight even in the mealy mouthed words of its Chairman is desperate and when it will have to cut programs to the ridiculous situation described in the extract from the Canberra Times this morning, legislation is being debated which will increase concentration of commercial ownership, which will increase the power of the major commercial proprietors in the capital cities and which will increase domination of commercial radio and television by foreign companies. All these things are happening in the one Parliament at the same time. It is an indictment of the total lack of broadcasting policy of this Government. It is an indictment of the disrespect which it has for great institutions such as the ABC and its many viewers and it is a total abdication of the so-called philosophy of the Liberal Party both in terms of the Liberal Party platform and that turgid speech made in Adelaide on 5 December last year when the Prime Minister talked at such great length about the Liberal Party's commitment to diversifying power from various sources.

In summary, the ABC is one of our great institutions and it should not be allowed to decline further. That comment is qualified by noting the poor decision making of the commissioners and some members of management. Those defects of the Commission, of senior management and, more particularly, of Government policy should not be allowed to destroy the integrity, the hard work and the talent of many broadcasters, producers, and production staff and so on of the ABC who remain with it in spite of a great drift away from it in recent years in search of better salaries and conditions. The quality of management in the ABC-one would hope the quality of the Commission itself-will be a subject of comment and discussion no doubt in the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, commonly known as the Dix Committee. What the Government does with the Dix report will of course be an interesting subject, and I hope the subject of considerable debate in this chamber. That report should be debated in this Parliament as soon as possible because the situation in the ABC has now reached such a parlous state that something has to be done in quite a dramatic way to restore the integrity and fortunes of the ABC.

I do not know what it is about the philosophy of this Government which is so distinct from the philosophies of all the successful democracies of western Europe and Great Britain, but somehow in this country we cannot even have pride and concern for the preservation and enrichment of a great national broadcasting service such as the ABC. It is part of the sordid, narrow-minded commercial priorities of this Government that it has no sensitivity or concern for those sorts of issues. It is about time it showed such concern because there are many thousands upon thousands of Australians who still regard the ABC as a great institution because of the vast range of services which it is still capable of providing on the sort of shoestring budget that it is given by this Government.

Funding for the ABC has to be maintained at its 1979-80 level as promised by this Government, that is, with adjustments for increased costs and consideration of extra expenditure on their merits. It is about time that this Government did something about honouring the promise which was made nearly three years ago to provide triennial funding for the ABC. That is yet another promise of the Fraser Government which has been totally ignored and dishonoured and which the Chairman of the ABC felt it important to draw attention to on Tuesday of this week. All of those matters require attention from a complacent, cynical and indifferent Minister. They are matters which I hope the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), who purports to represent the Minister for Communications in this place with the strange answers to questions he gets from the other side, will be able to convey to the Minister for Communications and, indeed, to the Prime Minister, because they are now becoming matters of national concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate today concerns itself with two alleged matters. The first alleges excessively new stringent financial restrictions on the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the second is the assertion by the Labor Opposition that there is a threat to the Commission's future ability to comply with its charter. I listened carefully to what Senator Button had to say in order to learn the extent to which he addressed the two matters which made up the content of the letter he put to the President to bring on this matter of public importance. I found too little material to justify the claims. I was dissatisfied and disappointed with what he presented to us. He put out his socialist paradigm. He was talking down the ABC and its present performance. He completely failed to identify the important place which the ABC plays, can play and is playing in Australian life today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting at this time of year to identify that we are in the run up to the Budget. This is the time of year when all the vested interests-the people who wish to press legitimately for their own Budget allocations-come out of the woodwork and come to Canberra from all areas. The ABC of course is one of the organisations which is fighting for its Budget allocation. However, after listening to some of the honourable senators opposite over a series of weeks, I find that what has emerged is a fairly constant litany that the Opposition will agree with any group of any kind seeking support for anything because, of course, not being in government, the Opposition is not answerable for what it says. Secondly, it constantly recommends increased expenditure and of course will oppose any measures to impose taxation. That is the classic kind of formula-lower taxes and higher expenditure in all areas. A nation simply cannot run that way.

In building a Budget a government must work out the resources that are available to it and how they should be shared, what the revenue flow from taxation is to be, what is to be the mix of expenditure and how is that to be apportioned between different areas of government activity. Anyone who is involved in government must be able to address these questions with honesty and directness. Sometimes that means saying to one group or another that it too must play its part in any restriction of overall expenditure or can share in any increased expenditure that is available.

The current situation concerning the ABC is that the Government has made certain general decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions on the need to exercise restraint on overall expenditure in respect of all departments and functions. I believe that defence alone has been excluded. These decisions have application to all government departments and statutory authorities. The ABC is part of that structure-part of that decision-but is in no way being singled out for attack. It is strange for an Opposition to call for greater tax cuts at various times, to give the Government lectures about tax indexation and taxation generally, and then to oppose any effort to restrain Commonwealth expenditure. The ABC is not being singled out. It is part of the exercise of general restraint.

Budget desisions for 1981-82 in relation to the ABC have not yet been taken. Senator Button puts us at a disadvantage because he argues from figures which are not available to me. I am sure that they are not available to my colleague, Senator Teague, who will speak later. We cannot determine the validity of the figures that the honourable senator has put before the Senate. One can only really argue as to whether the ABC has been properly treated when one sees what its Budget allocation turns out to be in the end. The facts on the table then give us a basis for argument and debate.

Senator Teague asked a significant question by way of interjection a short time ago: 'What is the evidence for the figures that you are putting out; where do they come from?' If we had such evidence we could discuss them, but in the end it would be the Budget statement, to be brought down in August, that would tell us what will be available to the ABC, to any department of State or to any statutory authority. We are dealing now with speculation based upon statements made by persons with a proper vested interest in looking after their own organisation and activities, but a vested interest nevertheless. Such submissions can have no reality in the run-up to the Budget presentation-until there has been a Budget Cabinet and Budget allocations have been determined and presented in public. Prior to that stage, it is a matter of speculation and nothing more.

I repeat, Budget decisions in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Commission have not been taken. In fact, estimates discussions on ABC funding for the coming financial year continue. Recently the Government asked the Commission to justify its claims in respect of areas for which it has sought additional funding. I put it to honourable senators that the Government, by seeking justification for the extra funding sought, has left the door open for negotiation with the ABC on a number of areas. It is not possible for any honourable senator to say with certainty what the allocation to the ABC will be. Therefore, it is not possible for people to draw conclusions as to what consequences will flow from ABC funding for 1981-82. People simply do not know what the level of funding will be, and because they do not, they cannot know what its effects will be. It is not the practice of the Government, nor has it ever been, to outline specific Budget provisions prior to the presentation of the Treasurer's Budget statement of August and I do not expect that the provision to be made for the ABC will be announced in advance this year either.

The position of the ABC is no different from that of any other statutory body or department concerning decisions taken following the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions. That review was a genuine effort by the Government to examine its own operation in an effort to rationalise it, to cut out fat and to eliminate unnecessary functions. I have a great admiration for the Australian Broadcasting Commission but I have observed that usually when outside broadcasts or interviews are conducted and teams are present from both the ABC and commercial television stations, the ABC has more people to do the job than do its commercial counterparts. That merely leads one to wonder whether the Australian Broadcasting Commission operation runs as leanly as it might.

The Review of Commonwealth Functions was designed to contain the size of the public sector and the reasoning behind that is well known to most Australians. The Government is determined to keep the growth of the public sector within what seems to be appropriate limits. Australian Broadcasting Commission expenditures are considerable. It is interesting to note that Senator Button did not bring them out during his contribution to the debate. In 1975-76, the ABC received a little more than $137m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peanuts.

—Senator Ryan interjects 'peanuts'. It will be interesting to see how the honourable senator responds in regard to every other request. She wants big government, high expenditure and therefore, by inference, wants higher taxation of the Australian public. There is no other way in which her kind of progamming could be accommodated. In fact, if she is a high expenditure senator she is a high tax senator. The budgetary provision for the ABC has risen progressively from $137m in 1975-76 to more than $183m in 1980-81. The Opposition asserts that that is excessively stringent. Perhaps Senator Ryan, who is to follow me in this debate, will indicate the amounts that she thinks should have been provided and how high they should have been. As I have mentioned, the allocations have risen from $137m to $183m over the term of office of the Fraser Government. If those increases are not what the ABC wants, let me add that the increases that are given to any department probably are not what that department wants. Most departments and statutory authorities can spend more money than they are given and have plans for expansion and extra programs which they could put in place if funding were available, but the job of government is to divide the cake in what seems to be the most appropriate and equitable manner. No one can say that, given that increase from $137m to $183m, the charge that this is an excessively stringent government allocation can be sustained in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that the first political letter I ever wrote as a teenager was to my local member concerning the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I asserted at that stage, as I still do, that the ABC should be able to carry out its functions and public duty free of political interference. I received a response from a former very distinguished member of this Parliament, Mr Harry Turner, who was my local member for many years. In taking up my point about the ABC, he presented to me the first reasoned understanding that I had had of the complexities which faced the ABC as a government instrumentality and of the interdependent relationships and responsibilities between it and the rest of the public sector.

It is in that kind of context that I am interested to see that decisions relating to the ABC will be made not in some kind of isolation, not apart from other decisions affecting government functions, not apart from considerations affecting other statutory authorities, not apart from considerations of how welfare will be helped or how taxation policy will be formed but against the background of consideration of all these matters as an integrated whole and as part of Government Budget strategy.

As well as that, the Australian Broadcasting Commission is under examination at the moment. Honourable senators will be aware that the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Dix Committee, has been established. It will report shortly on the services policy and the performance of the Commission. It is an evaluation exercise, if one likes. It is proper that any government instrumentality, department or function should be placed under review. The Review of Commowealth Functions was one such review from which a number of decisions flowed. The Dix Committee inquiry is another review. That review will examine the funding arrangements of the ABC including forward planning, budgeting and the revenue question.

The Government will consider the financial position of the ABC not only in the Budget context, which I have outlined, but also in the context of the Dix Committee inquiry and in the light of the recommendations which it makes. The Committee of Review is in existence. I believe its report is ready. I know from questions asked this week that honourable senators assert that it is in the hands of the Government, and it may well be, but no Budget decision on the ABC have yet been made relating to 1981-82. There is a need for the ABC to be seen to be functioning with other departments and with other authorities in line with the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Of course, a need exists for the Government now to consider the results of the inquiry which it commissioned before it makes any major changes to funding or to policy with relation to what has been properly called by Senator Button a valuable national asset.

I have seen details of Mr Norgard's statement of 2 June. I do not intend to comment on his particular propositions. Let us not forget that Mr Norgard's function is to act not as a dispassionate observer-I have no doubt he could do that with a different brief and under different circum- stances-and not as a disinterested public official. His function is to be there as an advocate of his authority. I read his statement when he is wearing the hat of Chairman of the ABC as that of an advocate who is putting a case for his authority and who is presenting the matter in a way designed to be most likely to bring about the kind of result he wants. The kind of result he wants, of course-again, it is a proper result for an advocate-is the most favoured funding, the most favoured treatment and the best result for his own particular organisation. Of course, I read the kind of consequences which he proposes. I wonder whether they were not made, as it were, to create a pressure point upon those who have to make decisions.

Senator Button referred in the letter which he read, but not in his speech, to the charter of the ABC-a charter which requires the Commission to provide adequate and comprehensive programming. I join with honourable senators in hoping, requiring and expecting that the ABC will in fact meet and satisfy that charter. The issue which has been raised by the Opposition has to be examined in the light of Australia's cirumstances. It is not an open cheque policy which can be applied to the ABC any more than it is a blank cheque policy that can be applied to any department of State. What is ahead of us is the question of how we balance the use of available resources to maximise equity between functions and how we do it to maximise efficiency within any particular function. That is the issue facing every organisation. It is an issue facing the ABC no less or no more than any other organisation. The goal which any government must seek to satisfy is to provide or to make possible the provision of first class programming with variety, standard setting and access to the national network. The ABC is our flag bearer in many of these functions but it must operate in terms of its funding and resource base as part of a co-ordinated plan by government.

The question of equity between sectors is one which cannot be ignored. Certainly in the debate to this stage there has been no demonstration of excessive stringency. There has been no demonstration that stringency has been of a degree which would threaten the Commission's future ability to comply with its charter. As I have said during this debate the negotiations on the Budget are continuing. It is not possible for any Opposition senator to assert that he knows what the Budget outcome will be because to do so would be patently ridiculous. I emphasise once again what I said earlier. The ABC is being examined by the Dix Committee which will assist government and, no doubt, will determine new long term policies and directions which this great national body might wish to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance introduced into the Senate today by my colleague, Senator Button, in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's excessively stringent financial restrictions on the Australian Broadcasting Commission which threatens the Commission's future ability to comply with its charter.

I must express my disappointment with the statements made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represents in this place the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). Instead of addressing himself to the very serious and very concerned criticisms and issues raised by Senator Button on this subject, which is of concern to all Australians, the Minister instead has delivered himself of a rather pedestrian homily about the difficulties of public expenditure.

Insofar as his remarks had any theme or consistency at all it was that public sector expenditure must be cut across the board. The Minister's theme was that if the Government is going to cut expenditure for one sector it has to be cut for all and it is not proper to distinguish between the functions of the various public departments and statutory bodies which are being dealt with. I suppose that really does demonstrate just what the Fraser Government thinks of the ABC. The Fraser Government accords no special position to our national broadcasting service. The Fraser Government is not prepared to give recognition to the historical achievements of that national broadcasting service in education, culture, bringing services to remote areas, technological innovation and so forth. So far as the Fraser Government is concerned, the ABC is just like the Department of Supply-an area of public expense. Therefore in itself it is repugnant to this excessively capitalistic, ideological government. It is an area of public expense which deserves no special consideration for the role it plays in our society.

The point of view of the Australian Labor Party is quite different from that. It is quite contrary to that in fact. So far as the ALP is concerned, public expenditure ought to be so tailored as to meet the needs of the functions on which the money is being spent. We do not see the ABC simply as another tedious area of public expenditure. We acknowledge that, in our democratic society, an objective, independent national broadcasting service is integral to the proper functioning of that democratic society. In the particular circumstances which apply in Australia where we have a very decentralised population, a far flung population and large areas where people live in remote and isolated places, the unifying effect of a national broadcasting service cannot be over-emphasised. If it were not for the ABC, I would say that national life in Australia would be far more fragmented, far more disunified and far less coherent than it is. It has been the historical role of the ABC to inform citizens in virtually any part of Australia about current affairs, the actions of governments, and to bring to them Australian culture, news and culture from overseas and to raise the educational standards of the Australian population. It is that national role, that unifying, informing and developmental role, that we believe gives the ABC the entitlement to be treated a little differently from, say, the Department of Transport. It is that role which the Fraser Government rejects, has no time for and, indeed I would say, in a rather sinister political way actually wishes to downgrade. It is clearly not in the interests of the present Government so intent on perverting public debate, on concealing the realities of our economy from the community and on making the way easy for its own friends and supporters to gain control of all business and communications in this country, to have an independent and objective source of information and comment for the Australian people.

The Minister also said that it was improper or irrelevant to raise the question of the future budget of the ABC because we do not know the details that the 1981 Budget will contain. Of course we do not. But it is our job, as a responsible Opposition, to look at the record of the Fraser Government with regard to funding the ABC and to make very informed speculation about what is in store for the ABC. With new cuts being announced prior to the Budget and prior to the report of the Dix committee-most untimely-we can only properly speculate that the ABC will continue to be singled out for especially harsh treatment, as it has been so singled out for the last 5 1/2 years of the Fraser Government.

The Minister complained that there was insufficient evidence of that particularly harsh treatment of the ABC. Let me give him some of that evidence. During its period in office the Fraser Government has forced a cut in the ABC staff of 1,150; that is, 7,350 jobs have been cut to 6,200. It has now ordered a reduction in salary expenditure by a further 2 per cent-the wonderful across-the-board technique which Senator Baume is so happy to defend. That will bring the total cut to 1,400 positions or just under 20 per cent of the ABC's staff in five years. Nowhere during the period of those cuts have we seen a proper justification of them. I stress that the Labor Party is not interested in bureaucracy for bureaucracy's sake or in public sector jobs for the sake of public sector jobs. We are interested in efficiency and performance. In terms of those two criteria we have never had from any of the Ministers responsible or from the Fraser Government a justification for cutting the staff of the ABC by 20 per cent in five years.

The Minister said that there had been no particularly harsh treatment of the ABC compared with the rest of the public sector. That is simply not true. By comparison the overall Commonwealth Government work force between 1975 and 1980 was cut by less than one-half of one per cent but by 20 per cent for the ABC. Yet the Minister has the effrontery to say that there has been no especially harsh treatment of the ABC. In terms of funding also the ABC has been singled out for discriminatory treatment by the Government. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of figures which illustrates the funding of the ABC since 1974-75.
