TALK.START.PARA: —Those figures show that since 1974-75 the ABC has sustained a funding cut in real terms of 22 per cent. Its budget, as a proportion of total government outlays, has declined from 0.83 per cent in 1974-75 to 0.6 per cent in 1980-81. There again we have a real and large cut which is out of all proportion to cuts which other government authorities have sustained. In 1979, when Tony Staley was Minister for Post and Telecommunications, he indicated that cuts in the ABC were to end. I think many of us will remember the fanfare and triumph with which that progressive matter was announced. There was to be triennial funding tied to an agreed base figure and indexed for inflation. We were told that the ABC now had a stable base for forward planning. That promise was confirmed in the 1980 Budget Speech, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the period 1981-82, subject to review as necessary, the annual provision to be made for the ABC should not be less than the initial appropriation for 1979-80 after due allowance has been made for cost increases.

The Opposition, the ABC and the general public welcomed that announcement and that commitment. We welcomed the Government's promise that there would be a stable base for funding for the ABC. What do we now discover? As in so many areas of public promises made by the Fraser Government, that promise has been abandoned. We now find that the Government has perpetrated another massive deceit on the Australian public; that, despite Government assurances, the ABC's 1981-82 budget will not be indexed to inflation. On top of that the ABC will be subjected to a further 3 per cent cut in non-salary expenditure. The triennial funding announced by Mr Staley and confirmed in the last Budget, like so many other of the Fraser Government's promises, has been abandoned. Cuts to the ABC are more visible than cuts in other areas of Commonwealth departments and authorities. For five years we have been watching deteriorations in ABC programs, the downgrading of radio and television current affairs and the replacement of Australian drama with cheap British imports. I do not believe there is a senator in this place who cannot confirm what I have said. Although for a period I was responsible for this portfolio and, therefore, attracted a lot more correspondence on the topic than I do in my normal duties as a senator, I have been inundated with complaints from the general public about those deteriorations I have just enumerated-the lack of Australian content, the downgrading of news and current affairs and the downgrading of sport. All of us have received constant complaints from the general public about the inability of the ABC to perform the functions that the general public wants it to perform and is prepared to pay for it to perform. I would like to quote from a short article which appeared in the National Times of 24 May 1981. It is typical of recent reports about the ABC. It stated:

Funds are apparently so tight in the ABC that it can no longer afford to send its Australian-based correspondents on overseas trips-not even with the Prime Minister . . . In another puzzling decision, the ABC hierarchy have decided against appointing a national political correspondent at least in the short term. The post has now been vacant for about four months.

Those are the sorts of things that we have serious complaint about. How can the ABC bring to the people of Australia proper, up to date and informed news and comment when it no longer has a correspondent in Canberra and when it can no longer send a correspondent to accompany the Prime Minister, even when he makes overseas visits? That is the manner in which the Fraser Government is destroying what was once a strong and independent national broadcasting organisation. Another area which has suffered greatly is television drama. In 1974-75 the ABC produced 156 hours of television drama. This year it will produce about 70 hours of television drama, about 45 per cent of the 1974-75 output.

TALK.START.PARA: —Features like Ben Hall we don't see any more.

—Senator Mulvihill reminds us by interjection of features such as Ben Hall, Seven Little Australians and Rush-wonderful creative examples of what the ABC, when given an appropriate level of funding and staffing, can achieve and programs which were extraordinarily successful and popular with the Australian public. That is what the Australian Labor Party is really concerned about. What sorts of services is the Australian public getting from the ABC? That is the first question to be asked. The other questions which Senator Baume raised about across the board cuts for public expenditure and so on, of course, have their place. But the national broadcasting service is there to provide, as contained in its charter, adequate and comprehensive broadcasting of the highest standards to all Australians. That is not being done.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to Australian drama, I have a copy of a telegram sent to Mr Sinclair from the following organisations: Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia; Australian Society of Authors; Australian Writers Guild; Producers and Directors Guild of Australia; and Film and Television Production Association of Australia. I do not have time to read that telegram but it points out the dreadful effects of the cuts in television drama production and the effect that this has had on the whole of the creative work force working in those areas in Australia. The further cuts that have already been announced will leave the ABC with very few options for coping with such cuts.

One of the matters that has been of great concern to the general public and the Federal Opposition is that some of the most talented and experienced journalists, directors, producers and so on are being drained away from the ABC. I point out to a government which is so concerned with restraining the public purse and avoiding wastage of public money that every time one of those talented, experienced journalists, producers or technicians leaves the ABC and goes to the commercial sector there is a waste of the public investment in that person. Those people have been trained at public expense by the ABC. They have gained their experience by working in the public sector in broadcasting and they are being forced out through inefficiencies in administration and inappropriate structures of the ABC but mainly through Budget cuts administered in such an irrational and chaotic way that they are unable to do the work for which they are trained. They are a great loss to the Australian public generally in that their services are no longer available nationally, but to the specific organisations they go to, and also because they have been trained and gained their experience at public expense. I wish that the Government would think a little bit more carefully about its fanatical concern about public expenditure when it makes these decisions.

Finally, the fact that the new cuts have been announced when we are waiting for the first massive investigation into the role and structure of the ABC is a very bad omen. These cuts are most untimely. They suggest that the Government will not be responding positively to the Dix Committee's report and will not be taking the opportunity, which I hope and expect that the report will present, to allow the ABC to be again what it has been historically-a great national broadcasting institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate is debating the allegations raised by the Opposition in this so-called matter of public importance of excessively stringent financial restrictions placed by the Government on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I reject that. I believe that this is a premature debate because it relates to the Budget. The Budget will come down in mid-August. It is then appropriate for the Senate to discuss the Government's provision for the Australian Broadcasting Commission as well as the Government's provision for every other area of government spending. It is also premature because only this week, I understand, the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission has brought its substantial report with recommendations to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). The report has not been tabled in the Parliament. There has been some speculation in the Press as to the contents of the Dix Committee's findings. When that report is before the Parliament then it will be appropriate to talk about the very weighty matters of restructuring the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is entirely premature for the Opposition to allege a matter of public importance before the Budget is made clear and before the findings of the Dix report are made clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan, in her concluding statements, talked about an omen of cuts. She alleged that this omen is disconcerting as the Dix report is about to be brought down. These cuts and this omen are entirely speculation and rumour that have been put forward in the Senate, not on the basis of any government decisions and any clear announcement by the Minister, but rather on the basis of rumouring. These rumours have been exacerbated by the series of telegrams to which Senator Ryan referred from the Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia, the Australian Writers Guild, the Producers and Directors Guild of Australia and the Film and Television Production Association.

Those bodies, of course, have an interest in the discussions currently taking place in the run-in to the Budget. They are important vested interests. Of course, they will be doing all that they can to call for public discussion and to try to gain some public pressuring of the discussion that is leading to the Budget decisions. If the Opposition uses those rumours and allegations to try to put forward this so-called omen or this picture of the Government's cutting back of the ABC funds, they are alarmist and entirely premature. In the current year there has been a 15.6 per cent increase in government funding provided to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That is $183m compared with $158m last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about inflation?

—That more than accounts for inflation. There is a real increase in funding provided to the Australian Broadcasting Commission this year. Is that stringently excessive financial restriction? I ask the Senate and the Australian public whether they can see a real increase in this year's funding provided to the Australian Broadcasting Commission as being a restriction. There is increased expenditure. Why then has the Opposition raised this matter? As all honourable senators know there is provision in our Standing Orders for matters of public importance to be raised. If a matter is really urgently important and needs to be brought before the Senate an honourable senator, accompanied by some others standing in their places, can raise the matter and so have a matter of urgency added as a special item to the Senate's agenda for discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: The running of this procedure is left mostly to the Opposition and rightly so because that is the Opposition's role in the Senate. It so happens that we are coming towards the end of the session and Senator Button, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, has not had his turn. A matter has come up that is in his area of interest as shadow spokesman on communications. He is told: 'John Button, it's your turn. What can you drum up as a matter of public importance to raise in the Senate this week?' So it has come about that the Opposition has tried, as valiantly as it can to make some attempt-a hopeless attempt-to raise allegations and rumours about the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Members of the Opposition conveniently forget the marked increase in government commitment this year to the ABC. They conveniently forget that the discussion is premature and that the Budget discussions are only at the negotiating stage and still proceeding. They conveniently forget that the appropriate time for a full-bodied debate on the ABC is when the Dix report is tabled.

How is it that vested interests can gain the attention of the Opposition in this way? I will say how I believe this has arisen. I believe that when the ABC commissioners met in Sydney on Tuesday of this week they were nervous-anticipating the Dix Committee's report-about the whole structure of the ABC. They were nervous not only about their future as commissioners and the future priorities of programs within the Australian Broadcasting Commission but also that every area of the Australian Broadcasting Commission would be reported upon and reviewed by the Dix Committee. This week the report was pending and they thought it would be in the Government's hand. When the ABC commissioners met they put forward certain statements of a general kind about the dialogue currently being engaged in between them and the Government with the Budget in prospect.

Immediately, the secretary of the ABC Staff Association takes up one or two of the lines put out on Tuesday by the commissioners and starts a rumour that severe cuts are pending for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Of course the Press is interested and it interviews Mr Collis-George about this. He says: 'I have been to see the Chairman of the Commissioners, Mr Norgard, and I have put to him these fears that we and the Staff Association of the ABC rightly feel'. Mr Norgard does not fully assure him that his fears are groundless, but he listens to him. So Mr Collis-George is able to say to the Press: 'I have put these views to the Chairman of the Commissioners'. Then the Press, quite rightly, as is its investigative role, rings various interested bodies. It speaks to Mr Williamson, the President of the Australian Writers Guild, and to Mr Windt, the assistant general secretary of Actors Equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they say?

—They say: 'If these allegations are true then there may be programming cuts for the ABC and, therefore, there may be diminished opportunity for Australian writers and producers to gain their livelihood and to gain the kind of opportunities that they have had in the past or which they want to see expanded in the future. Of course, these vested interests-they are correct vested interests-will get on the bandwagon and start to exaggerate the position, saying that has begun. So the allegation runs that there may be restraints on expenditure in the ABC in the coming Budget. The Press reports of what the spokesmen for the writers and actors said gain not only this fear but also some red hot political statements. That always makes for good controversy; so it gets into the newspapers too. Mr Williamson said:

SPEECH.PARA: The obvious answer is that the Country Party feels the employees of the ABC are not the right political shade.
Mr Windt says:
Mr Fraser's political vindictiveness and single-minded determination to rub out the ABC is something to behold.

What ridiculous statements! What bias! What unfounded allegations against the Government parties and against the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)! But it is good controversial stuff and the media picks it up. Already in the last few days there has been a snowballing effect that there is something running in the ABC. I put it to the Senate that this is a series of allegations and a series of rumours which are in the nature of discussion in any run up to a Budget. Could we have had a matter of public importance, if it had been some other shadow Minister's turn today, about one or other area of public discussion on what the Budget may contain? We would have had the same sort of debate and it would have all been groundless because there is no firm Government decision. The only firm ground on which we can talk is on this year's Budget. In this year's Budget there is a 15.6 per cent increase in the Government commitment to the ABC. Even on the figures that Senator Ryan incorporated in Hansard, there is an increase on last year's Government commitment to the ABC of $187.8m, compared with this year and the greatly increased amount of $215.6m. They are the only facts--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in dollar terms. What about real terms?

—That is in dollar terms. In real terms there is another increase and it is shown in Senator Ryan's table. There is a real increase shown in the table. According to Senator Ryan and the Opposition, in real dollar terms the increase is from $111m to $116m in 1974-75 prices. So the table that Senator Ryan puts down shows that there is a real increase this year in the Government's commitment to the ABC. I believe that the matter of public importance alleged by the Opposition is entirely unfounded. It cannot claim that there have been excessive, stringent cuts. I find it ironic that the Opposition claims that the Commission's futureability to comply with its charter is being somehow jeopardised by the Government. That is the very question that is at the heart of the Dix Committee of inquiry. The whole ABC charter is to be reported upon by the Dix inquiry. How ironic it is that the Opposition seems to protest that that may be happening. This is not a matter of public importance; it is a matter of proper vested interests speculating and trying to lobby even the Opposition to raise some public attention in the hope that it may gain a little more in the Budget. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the report relating to the following proposed work:

SPEECH.PARA: Provision of Army housing at Townsville, Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Normally when reports of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works are tabled, they are tabled without any additional comment. But I believe this report raises some matters that ought to be brought more directly to the attention of the Senate. The reference was to housing to be provided for the Army in Townsville. The members of the Committee held long hearings into the problem. One problem that arises out of it and that I think deserves more attention is this question of scales and standards for Army housing. We found a great shortage of housing for Army personnel who had to move to Townsville. The whole purpose is to provide them with housing which, as the Army says, must meet scales and standards. One of the problems we found was that in many instances where good houses could be bought on the market, they were rejected by the Department of Administrative Services because they were above the Army's scales and standards. In some instances they were above the scales and standards because they had one extra toilet.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that concerned us was that whilst good houses could not be bought on the market and people were left in substandard houses or were not able to take their families to Townsville, we found that 1,142 of the houses in which Army personnel presently have to live in Townsville are below the scales and standards. When we say that they are below the Army's scales and standards, we mean that some of those houses had to be seen to be believed, especially when one takes into account the rent that one has to pay. But we are most emphatic on the point that this hiding behind firm scales and standards is not a sufficient excuse for the Government not to make the Department of Administrative Services buy houses on the market so that people who have to be stationed in Townsville can live in a decent fashion. But the matter went even further than the Department not buying houses because of the scales and standards. When people move into houses in Townsville they find that the houses do not provide a great many of the amenities that might make life more pleasant in that sort of area. They do not even have the sorts of amenities that people take for granted these days-amenities such as a barbecue. Honourable senators would have to admit that due to the climate in Townsville a barbecue may be a very pleasant way of entertaining or for the family to relax. To our astonishment we found that if a soldier moves into a house in Townsville, builds a barbecue in the back yard and then, as Army procedure seems to lay down, he must be moved on within two years, that barbecue is knocked over by the Army. It is entirely removed. It is not offered to the person next door or to the person moving into the house; it is entirely removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a scorched earth policy, Senator.

—Exactly. It is indeed a scorched earth policy. That barbecue has to be removed. Nobody is consulted; nobody is paid: It is removed. It seems to us to be absolutely absurd. To use such excuses as scales and standards is not really tenable. The Committee has discovered in inquiries that similar things are done in other areas of the defence forces. I found for instance that in the Air Force area in Laverton in Victoria things had to be returned to the state they were in when the tenant took occupancy. One tenant had gone into a house and set up a beautiful flower garden and a lovely vegetable garden. When that tenant moved out, Defence put in a rotary hoe and hoed up the entire garden, leaving it in that state for the next tenant. I think that this is like Gilbert and Sullivan. I think it is time that the defence forces caught up with reality or that some logic was applied to the situation, especially as Defence Force personnel are moved around Australia every two years with no thought given to the schooling of their children or to any career that their wives might have.
—A mad hatter's tea party, Senator.
—I think the mad hatter was logical compared to the Defence Force.
—Iolanthe or Trial by Jury?

—Iolanthe. Other matters came up that I think should be drawn to the attention of the Senate. In talking about the sort of house that should be built in Townsville, we were told that the Defence Department tended to try to build houses that fitted in with community standards. That is all very well but, if the community standard has been forced down because of economic conditions, because of the lack of work in the area and because people literally cannot afford to build to a higher standard, it does not seem to us to be logical that the Army personnel who are forced to go there should have to take the lowest common denominator.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking about the sorts of houses that should be built in a tropical area, we found that there was an extraordinary lack of imagination and a lack of willingness to look at a problem from a new point of view in the Department of Defence, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Housing and Construction. For instance, in our duties as senators we had discovered that in other places in Australia people had looked at such problems as housing in tropical areas and tried to introduce new ideas. We discovered that, in the Kakadu National Park, the National Parks and Wildlife Service had built for its rangers houses that provided comfortable living without power-supplied means of comfort such as air conditioners. The houses had been built to use the maximum of natural cooling devices to give people a pleasant life. That seemed to us to be an excellent idea.

It was interesting when we asked officers of the Department to comment that their first comment was that such houses were in excess of current Defence married quarters standards in that they had an additional water closet. It took them some time to get to the point that these houses also have natural ventilation, with a living area in a natural breezeway so that people could live in some comfort. They went on to point out that in their opinion these houses would have to be built on three conventional blocks. I question what sort of tape measure they took up with them. I have been in those houses and I swear that they do not provide any more accommodation than does an ordinary suburban house, but, very sensibly, the cooking and bathing facilities are located in one block and the bedrooms-very ordinary sized bedrooms-are located in another block with this breezeway in between in which people can live and be comfortable. It is interesting that even the Department had to admit that the average cost of these dwellings is approximately $85,000, including a 40 per cent loading over and above Darwin costs. We all know that Darwin costs are over and above other costs in Australia.

It would be nice to think that the Department, after having had this situation drawn to its attention, would take a more imaginative and realistic look at problems of housing in various areas of Australia and get off its tail and go out and look for them. If a Senate committee can find them, one would think that a department could apply itself to finding other answers to the problems of housing in those areas.

The question of costs was one that intrigued us. As I have said, the overwhelming number of houses in which Army personnel have to live in Queensland are leased by the Commonwealth Government from the Queensland Housing Commission. The overwhelming majority of complaints by tenants in those houses leased by the Army is that no repairs, renovations or maintenance are done on the houses. When we asked the Army why that was so, it said that under the agreement it was unable to do any of that work on houses that it leased from the Queensland Housing Commission. Yet the tenants, the Army personnel, leaving those houses, have to pay for any wear and tear on the houses. If the walls are badly marked, if the floors are badly scratched, if the flywire has to be replaced in the screen doors, they have to pay the Army for repairs and renovations. Yet that money is not applied to putting the houses into some sort of decent order before new tenants come in. Departmental officers take a note of any damage, they tell us. They write in a book that there is a scratch on the floor or a hole in the wall, so that if when a tenant leaves there is a bigger hole he will be charged only for the extra size of the hole, and if there is another mark on the wall he will not be charged for the original marks but only for the new marks. But nobody fixes up the marks, the holes or the scratches.

The Senate will note in the report that the Department has put down a figure of $1.8m for renovations. One might be tempted to think that that money is to be used to put these houses at least back into the condition they were in before the Army moved in. But, no, that money is not to be used for that purpose. It is to be used for such things as venetian blinds, concrete under the ground and a lock-up shed if it is needed, but not to do maintenance. So we have houses in which water comes in, where the floor has fallen so that an almighty draught blows through and insects can get in. We have houses in which the stairs lean so that people are afraid of using them. We have all those problems, yet none of the Commonwealth departments can touch them. None of the money that is taken from the tenants to repair and renovate these houses is used for that purpose.

There is another interesting point in relation to the Commonwealth's association with the Queensland Government. The Commonwealth agrees that these houses will be rented by it for use by Army personnel. In our report we state:

. . . under the existing Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funds were provided by the Commonwealth to build these houses which are now rented back to the Commonwealth by the States at rentals ranging from $72 to $104 per fortnight. Of this amount, an average of $64 . . . per fortnight is collected by the Department of Defence as the Service tenants' rental contribution.

So there is a shortfall between the amount that we collect from the tenants and the amount that we pay Queensland. The story gets better. A telex that was sent to the secretary to our Committee reads:
The average rental paid (six houses) to the Queensland Housing Commission for married quarters occupied by Army personnel Captain or Warrant Officer rank in Townsville is $227 per fortnight.
I understand that these officers are charged $75 per fortnight by the Department of Defence.

I warrant that that $75 a fortnight is more than sufficient for some of the houses that those people have to live in; yet we are being charged by Queensland an average of $227 a fortnight. So we have an agreement to provide funds to build these houses, the Queensland Government pays interest on those funds and we subsidise it. We are in fact paying the interest on the funds that we are lending to the Queensland Government. Given the sorts of houses that we are getting for that price, I think that this is scandalous. I hope that the Government will take close note of what is going on in this area. We were led to understand that the same sort of agreement exists with every other State of the Commonwealth when it comes to defence housing. The States are using defence housing to milk the Commonwealth of funds. I do not think that this is good enough. It is sad because in the long run the State governments do not even provide decent housing with the money that they take.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Science and the Environment

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jessop) agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment:
The need for a co-ordinated approach to major land use problems in Australia, with particular reference to-
(a) the impact on the Australian environment of current land use policies; and
(b) the development of a co-ordinated national approach to land use policy having regard to the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth, State and local governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In conformity with Standing Order 448, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the debate on General Business Notice of Motion No. 41, standing in the name of Senator McLaren and relating to the setting up of a Senate select committee, being proceeded with forthwith.

This is a matter of extreme urgency. That is why I am taking this course. I had hoped that I would be extended somewhat similar courtesies as were extended to Senator Jessop. I gave notice of this matter on 27 May. I had hoped that it would be declared formal and a select committee would be set up. To acquaint the Senate with the notice of motion I gave for the setting up of a select committee and the need for it, I will read the notice of motion. It states:
(1) That a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report by 27 August 1981 on . . .

That is why it is so urgent. This inquiry could have been held during the winter recess when ordinary Senate committees are not so much bogged down with work. The Committee could have done its work and reported back to the Senate by that date. The notice of motion continues:

(a) the viability of the Ralkon Agricultural Company of Loveday Bay Road, Narrung, in the State of South Australia, and the competency of the Company to successfully farm (in the interests of the Aboriginal residents of Point McLeay) the three properties it now occupies;
(b) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council from the time of formation of the Company in 1975 until 30 June 1980; and
(c) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council and the Aboriginal Development Commission since July 1980.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent Resolution.

I have done that because in my view and in the view of many others, including the local district newspaper, the Murray Valley Standard, from which I will quote later to highlight the matter of urgency, the need for a full inquiry is a matter of urgency, as I will now relate to the Senate.

Three years ago the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was given a reference to inquire into the management and financial affairs of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd, Narrung, South Australia. Unfortunately for all concerned, nothing was achieved by this reference, which was passed on to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, whose report has never been made public. I have spoken to Professor Richardson about this matter. Under the terms of the Ombudsman Act, he is unable to make that report public because of certain things that happened. The inquiry dragged on for so long-I will not relate the details at this time-and the Aboriginal people at Point McLeay became so frustrated that they wrote to the Ombudsman and told him that they thought that they were getting somewhere with their problem and they asked him not to continue with his inquiry, although the report had been written.

Subsequent events now call for a more far-reaching inquiry than was thought necessary in 1978. Senator Baume, who was the Chairman of the Social Welfare Committee at that time, is fully conversant with all the problems that were abroad in that community at that time. At his request, I wrote to him on 6 June 1978. He wanted some information about the company and its problems. I gave him a quite large document. I do not need to go into that today because he is well aware of the problems there from the letter which was sent to him as Chairman of that Committee. On 26 June 1978 the Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Co., Mr Koolmatrie, wrote to Mr Thomson, the Secretary of the Social Welfare Committee, at the request of Mr Thomson, and gave him the history of the company and details of the problems that that company was facing. It is a quite lengthy document and is on the record of the Committee. No doubt Senator Baume is fully conversant with the contents of that. He had two documents-one from me as a senator who was approached by these people to do something to help them and one from the Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Co., Mr Koolmatrie, who unfortunately has passed away.
On 24 August 1978, Senator Baume put down a statement in the Senate which is on the record. I will not take the time of the Senate by relating it, except to say that he said:
Mr President, on 31 May 1978 the Standing Committee on Social Welfare received from the Senate the following reference:
The management and financial affairs of the Ralkon Agricultural Company Proprietary Limited, Narrung, South Australia.
He went on to say:
. . . we informed the Company of our view that recourse to the Ombudsman could be appropriate and might be available.

Subsequent events revealed that the Committee then passed the reference which it was given by the Senate to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I have already told the Senate that, because of certain happenings, that report has unfortunately never been made available. With the benefit of hindsight it might have been better if I had moved three years ago that a Senate select committee be set up; and we may not have been faced now with all the problems that exist in that area. On 24 April 1980, Senator Elstob, who was a member of that Committee, put down a statement in the Senate. I spoke at some length on that statement. I have repeatedly raised the matters before Estimates committees over the years, long before that reference was given. There is plenty of information on the record for anyone who would like to read about the problems faced by that company.

Last year, the company and the Aboriginal people living in the community were so frustrated that they put out this 8-page document setting out their history and the problems they faced. That document was sent to every member of the Federal Parliament and to every member of the State Parliament in South Australia. So no member, if he read his correspondence, can use the excuse that he was not fully informed of the viability of this company and the problems it is now facing. The reason why this matter is urgent now is that the media have taken it up. The local Press including the Adelaide Advertiser has taken it up and Channel 7 has run several programs on it in its current affairs program. One program containing interviews with the Aboriginals concerned is available in the Parliamentary Library. But I will not refer to all that in detail because I know that I am restricted, under this Standing Order, to pointing out why the appointment of a Senate select committee is so urgent.

In the Murray Valley Standard of 3 July 1980, the column, 'Viewpoint', which is the equivalent of an editorial in any other paper, is headed 'Black prospect'. Senator Baume would also have a copy of this article because I sent all this information to Senator Chaney when he was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He would have as much information on this as I have. No doubt the minutes were passed on to Senator Baume when he took over from Senator Chaney as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I will not read the editorial in full because it made some very unkind remarks about Senator Chaney, and that is not the purpose of my exercise today. The editorial states in part:
The Ralkon people have convinced us that they don't want to be treated like 'native children', but as the successful farmers they've proved they are.
The editorial continues:
They've convinced us. . . Who should they approach now for a fair deal?
A further 'Viewpoint' editorial of 2 October 1980 referred to the problem as a 'Black hole'. Part of that editorial states:
Too many of us, though, are prepared to ignore the problems, and to accept the empty theory that 'more money and a bigger public service will make everything OK'.
The record proves us wrong.
Now is the time for reasonable people to demand reasonable answers-or that black hole will just keep getting bigger.

That is one of the reasons why the need for an inquiry into this matter is so urgent and why it should be conducted without delay. On 12 January 1981, Mr Bill Nankivell, the previous Liberal Party member for Mallee in the State electorate in which this company is situated, wrote to Senator Baume. I point out that Mr Nankivell was a well respected member of parliament and he is still a well respected member of the community. He is chairman of a consultative committee. I will quote only parts of that letter to Senator Baume because Senator Baume will be well conversant with it. He has it on his file. Mr Nankivell wrote:

As you are no doubt fully aware, there are factional problems on Pt McLeay, one faction associated with Ralkon and the other working through the Community Council which appears to have the support and advice of the Regional Department. Consequently, we as a Consultative Committee to Ralkon, find that we are called upon to provide legal advice more often than managerial and financial advice and as a consequence have quite unintentionally become involved in these factional arguments.
The present Committee consists of myself as Chairman, Mr Wayne Sanders, a local District Councillor and neighbouring farmer--
I know Mr Sanders very well. He is very well respected in the community around Meningie-

Mr Graham Perrin of Giles & Giles Pty, the Accountants for Ralkon and Mr John Daenke of Genders Wilson & Co., the solicitor and legal advisor for Ralkon-together with Mr Ian Hillock, the Manager of Ralkon.
He went on to say:
The proof of the success of Ralkon is that it has survived and been reasonably profitable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I can understand my colleague's concern but I simply want your advice. Under Standing Order 448 he is trying to establish the urgent necessity for the setting up of a Senate select committee. I simply ask you and him: Are we now straying on to the substance of the matter affecting the Ralkon community and its relations with those at Point McLeay? That really is the substance of the inquiry. With very good will, I just want to know: Can the honourable senator restrict his remarks to the urgent necessity for the suspension of Standing Orders?

—Under the Standing Orders the basis of the ability of an honourable senator to speak is to stress the urgency of the matter but he cannot debate the subject matter. I ask Senator McLaren to bear that in mind.

—Thank you, Mr President. As I said in my opening remarks, I am well aware that I am restricted in what I can say. My Whip had negotiations with the Government Whip to see whether this committee could be set up and we were told no, the Minister would not agree. That is why I have had to take this action in the Senate to try to get the Senate to agree. I am not asking for anything outlandish. To prove my point as to why the matter was so urgent I felt I had to refer to some of those matters. However, if Senator Baume does not want me to do so, I suppose that under the Standing Orders he can prevent me from doing so.
—I am just asking for a reasonable debate.

—That is what I was trying to point out, Mr President. I am not the only one asking for this inquiry because Mr Nankivell who is the chairman of the consultative body advising Ralkon and who was also the local State member for many years is also concerned. I was trying to point out some of the matters which he has drawn to Senator Baume's attention, to the problems which exist at Ralkon and how, in my view, whoever is in the right, we could get to the kernel of the matter if this Senate committee were to be set up and were allowed to do its work. It will not be at any great cost to the Government, I am sure. Because the Minister has intervened, I have now run off the track, and I will have to leave that paragraph on page 2. But I do want to refer to the latter part of Mr Nankivell's letter in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I wish to assure you that we as a Committee have only one desire and that is to see Ralkon be given a fair go and assisted in its further development and possibly used as a model for other such enterprises rather than it should be destroyed for petty reasons.
That is the real crux of the matter-petty reasons. The letter goes on:
At the moment the future of Ralkon has never been more delicately balanced.

There are other letters from Mr Nankivell to Senator Baume in his capacity as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I have copies of them but I will not refer to them today. As I said, this has become a public matter. It is getting a lot of publicity in the Press. In the Adelaide Advertiser of Thursday, 14 May, there is a statement by Mr Bourke of the Aboriginal Development Commission. According to the article, Mr Bourke, because of some report which he got from a farm management consultant, accuses the Aboriginals at Ralkon of poor farm management. The article is entitled 'Aboriginals' farm ''poorly managed'' '. This is of great concern to people. In the Adelaide Advertiser of Friday, 15 May there is an article entitled 'Ralkon report not disputed'. According to the article, Ralkon agrees with the report because it has not been able to get proper tenure of the land to work the property properly. The Murray Valley Standard of Thursday, 14 May carries an article headed 'ADC reply on Ralkon'. On 21 May, just a week or so ago, that same newspaper carried this article: 'ADC ''declared to overthrow'' Ralkon'.

All of these things are very confusing to many people. In my view, there is only one way to solve them and that is for a Senate select committee to be appointed to examine all of the problems which exist on both sides. As I have pointed out to the Senate, this is a very urgent matter and when I moved that Standing Orders be suspended, I asked honourable senators to agree with me. This matter has gone much further since 1978. The Aboriginal Development Commission has been formed and accusations have been made about the regional office of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. There have also been many problems associated with the previous local Aboriginal councils at Point McLeay. Fortunately there has been change but still a lot of things are simmering under the surface and they are causing great anguish to people in the community. The Murray Valley Standard of last week-I have given a copy of the article to Senator Baume-contains a photograph of the Minister talking to Aboriginal people at Point McLeay. The editorial in 'Viewpoint' is headed 'Dirty washing?' and states:
It seems more likely, however, that Senator Baume (like Senator Chaney before him) finds it more convenient to back off from what threatens to become a very messy issue.
It goes on to say:
Whose dirty washing is nearly on the line?
There's need for an official and open inquiry on the Ralkon farm controversy-right now.

That is why last week I gave notice of motion relating to the setting up of a Senate committee. I say to you, Mr President, and to Senator Baume that I had no idea at all on the day I moved that notice of motion that that editorial was going to appear in the paper. I was rather astounded that it coincided with my notice of motion. But I was pleased that it did because I thought it might help Senator Baume to agree to the setting up of this Senate select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was forward thinking on your part, senator.

—I have been involved in this problem for nearly 10 years now, ever since I have been a senator. It goes a long way back. I have expressed my concern on many occasions. Mr President, as I have pointed out to the Senate, this is a very urgent matter. I ask the Senate to agree to suspend Standing Orders to allow me to move motion No. 41 standing in my name on the Notice Paper which calls for the appointment of a Senate select committee to inquire and report as outlined in that motion. The date is in my motion. I have read it out. If the Minister would allow the committee to be set up, it could do its work and report back to the Senate when we resume. It will not inconvenience the running of the Parliament. Such would be the case if a select committee were to sit during the parliamentary session. As I said, the work can be done during the recess. I hope that that Senate inquiry will be able to talk to all people concerned, hear all points of view and let every person involved-everyone from Ralkon, the local people who live in the Point McLeay township, and officers from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-hear the points of view instead of learning of them through the Press. Also, let us get members of the ADC before the committee so that it too can be made fully aware of all the problems that exist. For those reasons, I have moved my motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the debate on General Business, Notice of Motion No. 41 standing in the name of Senator McLaren and relating to the setting up of a Senate select committee, being proceeded with forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and I do so briefly because we do not want to delve into the history of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. I was associated with this matter, before it had the additional farm, in the last days of my position as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is one company which has successfully grown. I think it made a $30,000 profit last year. There is a fight as to who should own the land. There should be no fight. It was land which was given to the Point McLeay Aboriginals' organisation which leased it out to a company, but now there is an allegation that there is influence on some departmental officers to get it away from the company which employs the manager and give it back to the people on the reserve. The council operating the reserve does not really want it. It decided to give it to the company. There are continual fights, including attempts to stack the Point McLeay Council meetings for the purpose of getting a decision one way one day and a decision the other way the next day. This shows the urgency of the matter. Ralkon is one of the few profitable Aboriginal ventures. It is now being run down by internal fighting. There has been some neglect of the property by virtue of the fact that no one knows the tenure of his occupation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know the answer. I do not know who is right or who is wrong. I have had discussions with the manager of the company and the assistant director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Adelaide. I cannot make the decision, and I would not attempt to do so. But in the meantime, a sound, profitable investment is running down. Seasonally, it is the right time for the property to be improved. It is time something was resolved. To resolve one point of view as against another point of view would solve nothing unless one had the full facts of the inquiry. A decision by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) or the Department would solve nothing, and those who felt left out would be disgruntled. There would be an opportunity for them all to put their case before a committee. I think there would be a consensus of opinion to abide by the decision to let the industry go on. But valuable property is being run down and neglected because of this internal fighting. It is important to have this inquiry at least before the season gets too far advanced so that superphosphate can be applied and planting can be undertaken. It is important to solve the matter at an early date. Therefore, I think it would be a shame if it were left until the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act 1946 to clarify the intention of certain provisions in the Act relating to the funding of student organisations at the University. This Act was amended in 1979 to introduce into the Act provisions to implement the Government's policy on the membership and funding of student organisations in universities and colleges. This policy includes the principles that membership of student organisations is to be voluntary, that there is to be no discrimination against students who elect not to join such organisations and that compulsory fees charged by institutions can be used only for the provision of amenities and services. Such fees are not to be used to support socio-political activities.

The 1979 amendments place on the Council of the University the obligation to ensure that these fees are used only in accordance with the requirements of the Act. A number of questions of interpretation have arisen in connection with the implementation of these amendments, and the Government has consequently decided that there is a need to amend the Act to clarify the intention of the amendments and to ensure, in particular, that compulsory student fees cannot be used, directly or indirectly, for purposes other than for the provision of amenities and services. The Bill is directed to clarifying the provisions of the 1979 amendments in three ways. First, it makes income derived from compulsory student fees subject to the same conditions as apply under section 29A of the Act to these fees. Second, it provides that where income is received by student organisations through the use of both compulsory fees and other income, it will be necessary to apportion this income in determining the proportions available for amenities and services and for other purposes. The third aspect is that the administrative costs of student organisations, including any allowances paid to office holders, are also to be apportioned to the extent that these expenses may be attributed to the provision of amenities and services. Only the proportion of such administrative costs that can be directly attributable to the provision of amenities and services may be funded from the compulsory fees.

The question of the use of income derived from compulsory student fees arises in such cases as where funds obtained from these fees are invested to earn income or where fees are applied to other purposes, such as the production of a student newspaper, that lead to income. It is the intention of the Government that income obtained in such ways should be subject to the same conditions as apply to the use of compulsory fees through the requirements of section 29A of the Act. The amendments I have outlined do not represent an essential change in the framework provided by the 1979 amendments. The principles that underlie the Government's policy towards student organisations will continue to be given effect under arrangements that recognise the legitimate role of the University Council in the management of the University. It will continue to be the obligation of the council to ensure that compulsory student fees are used only for the provision of amenities and services. With the clarification that the Bill provides on certain aspects of the 1979 amendments that have led to issues in their implementation, I believe that an appropriate framework will exist to regulate the funding of student organisations at the Australian National University. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I refer to my proposed amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill I wish to raise a matter which is of considerable concern to me personally as well as, I would imagine, to most other senators. As will be recalled, it was the Government's intention last evening for the Senate, within 24 hours of these four very contentious Bills having been introduced to complete both their second reading and Committee stages. As a consequence, we had to undertake a great deal of research into the Bills and take into consideration the debate that had taken place in the House of Representatives. The Government decided early this morning, because of the hour, to deal as a matter of procedure with only the first of the four Bills before the Senate and to continue the discussion with respect to the other three some time this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: When I arrived at my desk this morning I found that all of the papers dealing with the second, third and fourth pieces of legislation involved in the cognate debate had been removed. They included not only the Bills themselves and the amendments which the Opposition wished to move but also all of my notes of discussions with colleagues in the other place, which took account of my party's attitude on the matter. In their place, the Bills which were introduced subsequently, at a late hour last night, were upon my desk.

It is a serious matter that a senator, particularly one on the front bench with a certain responsibility to acquaint himself with the procedures and policies of his party in the other place, should find that all of his notes of discussions and research have been removed without his authority. That represents an interference with the personal papers of honourable senators. I would like to put a hypothetical case to you, Mr President. You will recall that we rose after 1 a.m. this morning. It is conceivable that an honourable senator who might wish to raise very confidential matters as a result of representations made by a constituent, having decided not to raise them because of the lateness of the hour, would leave his papers here, only to find next morning that they had completely disappeared. That is a disgraceful affair, an unforgivable interference in the rights of honourable senators.

It is true to say that I have raised the matter with the Government party and it has been considerate enough to postpone for an hour or so this morning the debate on this Bill so that we would be in a position to carry out further research and discharge our responsibilities adequately. I raise this as a matter of procedure because I do not believe that papers left on our desks should be interfered with. I concede that sometimes there is such a welter of papers before us that someone may decide to clean them up, but surely such papers could be put aside so that if they were not required the next day by the senator they could be disposed of. I realise that the officers of the Senate have attempted to remedy the situation but that it has not been possible.

That only emphasises the point that I raised yesterday concerning what is happening about the security in this place, the role of the Parliament, and the rights of honourable senators. I drew attention to the diminution that was taking place in that respect, a matter which I hope will be taken up by the Presiding Officers and by the Senate itself. I am sure that the experience that I have related might well have taken place in the House of Representatives also. Mr President, I direct your attention to the matter for the purpose not of engaging in a witch hunt but of establishing procedures which will ensure that the papers of individual senators are protected, that confidentiality is preserved and that such papers are not interfered with in any way whatever.

Surely we can expect the Senate to adopt a more responsible position in respect of this amendment than it did last night in respect of those that I have mentioned. We should examine the democratic process involved. Senators elected at the same time as were members of the House of Representatives are unable to take their seats until 1 July 1981, a delay of six or seven months. Thus the Government has been able to use its brute force, its strength of numbers, to impose upon the Parliament an arrangement which will exist for 10 years. If there had been some synchronisation in regard to members and senators taking their seats in the Parliament and thus reflecting the majority decisions made by the Australian electorate in the federal elections of 1980, we would not be in the position in which we find ourselves today. We would have had sitting in the Senate senators who were elected at that time. They would have been taking part in the determination, as indeed have those who were elected at the same time to the other place.

Although there is much talk of the need for electoral reform, I state clearly and unequivocally that the Labor Party will not support a four-year term for members of the House of Representatives unless substantial changes are made in regard to synchronisation between the House of Representatives and the Senate concerning fixed terms of office and a number of other needed improvements in electoral procedures in this country.

The provisions of this legislation would be regarded by any business organisation as normal day-to-day practice. That is to say, before rises are approved by the Commonwealth through its various agencies, with respect to the monopoly position that we have developed with Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines, there should be a cost allocation review on a sufficiently comprehensive and frequent basis. Approval of fare increases for the two major airlines should not be given just because the airlines themselves have made submissions when they feel like it simply to maintain profitability. Regular reviews and comprehensive reviews should be undertaken. Such a review has not taken place.

The purpose of the Opposition's amendment is to establish the principle that regular and frequent reviews should be undertaken and that the organisations involved, both TAA and Ansett, comply with the requirements of the government of the day to ensure that they are able to justify the increase in air fares both in their incomes and expenditures. We all know, of course, that air fares have more than doubled in the last year, that substantial increases have been approved but that no evidence at all has been placed before the Government or the Department of Transport in these matters. It is conceded, however, with respect to the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, the Holcroft inquiry, that TAA submitted a case for an increase in air fares in relation to the major trunk routes of Australia. Ansett did not, as the Holcroft inquiry indicated, make available a submission. Nevertheless, on several occasions the Government has approved increases in air fares. Of course, the Holcroft inquiry pointed out these deficiencies and indicated to the community at large the grave deficiencies of that mighty organisation which was taken over, as honourable senators will remember, in a coup by Sir Peter Abeles and Rupert Murdoch about a year or so ago. They were able to get the assent of this Government without seeking to justify in any way the massive increases in air fares which have been significant since the Fraser Government came to office.

Paragraph (2) of the Opposition's amendment seeks to show that because we have something like 11 million commuters using the airways of Australia a consumers' representative ought to be appointed to such a review organisation-a public inquiry concept. A representative of the travelling public ought to be involved in the review process to protect and demand the sort of information that normally would be available in any other type of commercial, public or private organisation. We find it incomprehensible that the views of the travelling public which, after all, contributes to the success of the airlines and contributes substantially to the profitability of the airlines, cannot be put in any way, shape or form. At no time does the travelling public have the opportunity to present a view to the Government not only in respect of the price fare structure but also in respect of the parallel scheduling of airlines. Parallel scheduling of flights has been referred to constantly in this Parliament by members of all political parties from time to time.

Reference also has been made to the lack of competition and the lack of concern for the rights of the travelling public. We have all expressed discontent about that matter. Sometimes we find that there are delays of two or three hours on some of the major trunk routes. We find that both TAA and Ansett have flights leaving within five minutes of one another which causes great inconvenience to the travelling public. We believe there is a case to be put-an unanswerable case-that the travelling public ought to have a representative appointed to represent what we must all surely concede is a justifiable point of view with respect to these matters. Paragraph (3) of the Opposition's amendment states:
Recognition of the profitability of the major airlines in the conduct of reviews by the Committee.

Surely we are entitled to question what is reasonable and unreasonable in relation to the profitability of airlines. No honourable senator on the Government side can tell us whether the profitability of the major airlines is high or low. No government supporter surely can justify this concept. I am referring to the free marketeer element of the Liberal Party, those who believe in market forces and who constantly parade and espouse that view about free market forces and about free enterprise. Honourable senators opposite ought to be prepared to support this amendment. The Opposition is saying that some consideration ought to be given to recognising what is fair or unfair profitability as a result of the regulatory influence and the non-competitive nature of the major airlines in this country.

Surely reviews should be held regularly. I have yet to hear any honourable senator on the Government side say that regular reviews should not be held. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) when speaking in the debate in the other place could not and did not justify the view that there is not a need for a regular review by the Independent Air Fares Committee of the activities of these two airlines. Despite the decisions which have already been reached in respect of the airlines agreement legislation which was debated in this place last night an opportunity now exists for those honourable senators who believe and espouse that philosophical position and who claim that there ought to be free competition and free enterprise to indicate their views. The Opposition believes it will be difficult for them to sustain their opposition to the amendment to which I am now referring.

I take the view that if in fact honourable senators opposite reject this amendment to the second reading of the Bill then they are unable to defend adequately the policies of the Fraser Government in these matters. It would be just another indication of the way in which this Government has been bought, lock, stock and barrel by the Abeles-Murdoch empire. Whatever those companies want the Government to do in respect of the airline industry and whatever those individuals want it to do in respect of our communications in this country, the Government is prepared to dance to the tune and react to the whims of those particular organisations and individuals. That caustic and critical view is held honestly by the Opposition. If in fact that is not so, then the Opposition challenges the Government to say that it sees nothing wrong with the amendment which I have moved.

After all, the Opposition is attempting only to establish the principle that proper business practices should be applied with respect to the way in which the airlines industry in this country operates. Proper business principles should apply with respect to the two companies that have been given a monopoly position, the two companies which are protected by guarantees and are protected as a result of this legislation. These two companies have now got themselves into a gilt edged position and, consequently, are not accountable either to the Parliament or the general public for their activities. Therefore, if honourable senators are in fact confident of their philosophical position then they will in fact give this amendment more consideration than they gave to the debate held yesterday.

No doubt East-West Airlines Ltd and the other small operators in our country are in an inferior position in respect of their capacities to have some influence on the air fare structure. I find it just incomprehensible as well as inconceivable that the National Country Party, which claims to represent the rural point of view-and the number of people in that political party is shrinking in the Senate-and particularly its representatives from Queensland must surely appreciate the disadvantages suffered by the small operator as a result of this section of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill is a much more important Bill because it seeks to change the status of Trans-Australia Airlines and the procedures under which it operated previously. This public enterprise was established very early in the 1950s and was the pride and joy of the Menzies Administration. It is a public enterprise which has even been defended by the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony) and many other members of the Parliament, including some honourable senators.

We are satisfied with its application as a government-owned airline operating as it does, within the restrictions of the two-airline agreement and with certain impediments to the way in which it operates against its principal rival and competitor, Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. We are satisfied that the Government has not made out a case. This is one of the ad hoc decisions made by the Government in respect of Commonwealth functions. Nothing in the second reading speech in this place of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) or in the other place of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) would justify the very dramatic change in the way in which this organisation will operate. It appears, superficially, to be an attractive proposition. Many people in the Australian community probably would be attracted to the ideas of participating in a public company operating by buying shares in this organisation, knowing as they do that it has the guarantee and the backing of the Australian Government. That, of course, is not the way in which it necessarily would operate. We have seen the example of the Caltex oil company's decision recently to float itself as an Australian public company. The greatest percentage of the shares in that operation were taken up by the big financial institutions in our country.

I think the Opposition is entitled to fear the motivation of the Fraser Government and is entitled to be concerned about what the Australian Government has in mind. It is a matter of considerable regret and a reflection upon the way in which the Fraser Government operates that a Bill of this consequence has to be dealt with at this late hour of the session. We ought to be able to permit every honourable senator to speak in respect of whether there are pluses or negatives and costs or benefits in this important instrumentality that has been with us from the 1950s to the 1980s, and whether there should be any change in the status of the organisation. If we exercise our right to discuss this legislation at length what will happen to the other pieces of legislation? They will be pushed through by use of the gag.

It is a national disgrace that we should be put in a position that a Bill of such consequence cannot even be dealt with in the normal way of being left over for consideration by the Parliament that was elected in 1980. I am about to sit down, not because the Opposition does not have any arguments or that it does not feel strongly enough about this Bill but because I wish to afford a brief opportunity for any other members of the Senate to put his point of view. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to refer briefly to the Freedom of Information Bill. SPEECH.PARA: That was my clear understanding of the situation but that appears to be a disputed matter.
