PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill provides what used to be called the general purpose payments-
—Are these cognate?
—Was the local government Bill also called on?
—Yes. The Bills are linked.

—Senator Gietzelt might want to take that up later. I know that Senator Gietzelt intended to speak on the local government tax sharing Bill. Provided Senator Gietzelt can do that in this debate, that should be acceptable. The Bill to which I am speaking is the Bill concerning revenue sharing and health grants to the States. These matters were the subject of a Premiers Conference early last month, out of which grew incidents which revealed the very ugly face of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government had decided to apply a fiscal strangle to the States in 1981-82. He boasted of his toughness with the States but, following the Monday night meeting, a suggestion appeared in certain quarters of the media that actually the Government and the Prime Minister had not been as tough as they would like people to believe they had been, which apparently damaged the Prime Minister's macho self-image. He then instructed the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to give what has become known under this Government as a background briefing to selected representatives of the media. That background briefing evidently was not as effective as the Prime Minister hoped it would be. It did not build up his macho self-image to the degree that he wanted. So the Prime Minister himself next night decided to give a background briefing to other members of the media. The background briefing under this Government, of course, has become standard Prime Ministerial equipment for misleading the Press and the public in a fashion for which the Government is not accountable.

This time the security broke down and he was caught with his pants down, to borrow a phrase. Highly damaging interviews with both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were recorded by the Australian Broadcasting Commission, among others. The response from the Prime Minister's chief Press Secretary, Mr David Barnett, in particular, but also others, was to storm the offices of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and to attempt to stand over the officers of the Australian Broadcasting Commission threatening, in one instance at least, that their careers would be finished if those interviews went to air. That revealed the real face of the Fraser Government in contrast to the phoney face of the Fraser Government which Senator Baume presented in a debate earlier today, mouthing pious platitudes about the need to maintain the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That is the phoney public face of the Fraser Government. The real face of the Fraser Government was shown by David Barnett and others on the afternoon of, I think, 6 May when they behaved like storm troopers, storming the ABC offices, bullying and, in one instance, threatening members of the ABC about censoring the news-that is what the exercise was about; it was an exercise in censoring the news, in Stalinism-and saying that if they went ahead and discharged their duty as journalists and as employees of the ABC and reported the news, their careers with the ABC would be finished.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was David Barnett leading the team?

—David Barnett was the leader of the pack. He was the chief storm trooper. That is the real face of the Fraser Government. Even more important than the sneaky and sordid media manipulation by the Prime Minister and his Press officer is that, as a consequence of the self-indulgence of the Prime Minister in giving that background briefing in which he told journalists that the State Premiers were mugs and could have got an extra $70m if they had not been such mugs, the Commonwealth will be in an untenable position in all future negotiations with the States. Never again will the Commonwealth be believed when it presents a financial offer to the States. The State Premiers and Treasurers inevitably will say: 'Do not give us that. Come on, what is your real offer? You do not really mean that, do you? We rememer what you did last time. You went tittle-tattling to the Press the next night and said that we were mugs to accept what you offered and that we could have got more. Come on, tell us what your real offer is this time'.
—It's not very dignified, is it?

—It is not very dignified and it sets a dreadful precedent. As long as this Government remains in office, the Commonwealth will be in a untenable position in every financial negotiation with the States. Equally intriguing, I think, are the glimpses of the Prime Minister's personality which the incident provided for us. The first thing it revealed was his fundamental insecurity in the office that he holds. A Prime Minister who was secure and confident in that job would not feel any compulsion to boost his macho self-image every day by proving he was tougher than everybody else-a basic insecurity, of course, which is well merited by the circumstances in which he finds himself. The second was his appalling judgment. Those matters must worry even the most amoral members of his party, as will his subsequent capitulation when he offered an extra $16m as a form of hush money to the Premier of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill fixes the amount of money for general purpose grants to the States and the Northern Territory for 1981-82. That amount is already fixed. The Bill provides that the ratio between that amount and the total Commonwealth taxation in 1980-81, which in fact is something over 99 per cent of total Commonwealth taxation, will determine grants for 1982-83 and beyond. The percentage or ratio which will establish the grants for all the States in any one year will be the ratio between Commonwealth payments in the next financial year and total Commonwealth taxation in this financial year. That ratio, in establishing the payment to a State in a particular financial year, will be applied to Commonwealth tax collections in the previous financial year. I know that sounds terribly complicated, but that is the way it is. The tax cuts after this year, because of those arrangements, will be to the extent of 20 per cent or thereabouts at State expense.

The Bill also provides that any surcharge or rebate subsequently allowed on Commonwealth taxation will not be allowed for in this calculation. We can certainly forget the latter, the rebate, but I note that this legislation provides an opportunity for the Commonwealth, should it choose to do so, to declare that Commonwealth tax rates are halved in a financial year and then impose a 100 per cent surcharge and raise the same amount of revenue. The catch would be that the States would get only half as much of the income tax component of the total taxation that they would otherwise have got. I am not suggesting that that is likely to happen. Even under this Government that would be an extreme case. Nevertheless, we have had tax surcharges imposed before by the Fraser Government. We are unlikely, to say the least, to get any tax rebates. Any tax surcharges imposed in the future will disadvantage the States to a greater extent than the Bill appears on the face of it to do.

I think it is appropriate to give a brief survey of Commonwealth-State financial relations through most of the 1970s. In 1973 an Act was passed by the then Australian Labor Party Government which established a base level of payments to the States and provided for future adjustments by a formula which added on to the previous year's payment increases in wages which, I stress, are normally ahead of increases in the consumer price index. It added increases in wages not increases in the CPI. It added population changes, which invariably were increases upwards, and multiplied the product of that sum by 101.5 over 100. In other words, it increased it further by 1 1/2 per cent. The 1975 Act compensated for wage increases and population growth and increased the 1.5 per cent betterment factor to 3 per cent.

In 1976 the present Government substituted for that arrangement legislation which provided a percentage of the current year's income tax to the States. In 1977 it modified that percentage and related it to the income tax received by the Commonwealth in the previous year. By 1977 even the more innumerate State Premiers had realised that that arrangement was less generous to them than the previous arrangement had been and they prevailed upon the Fraser Government to ensure that any State had the option of claiming its financial entitlement either under the 1977 Act or under the previous Act passed by the Labor Government in 1975. In other words, the net of the Labor Government legislation was put underneath all the States. In fact, in recent years, it was that net which determined the actual level of payments.

Those arrangements continued until the financial year 1979-80. With an election looming, the Government decided that the most politically expedient thing to do was to extend that level of payment for one further year, that is, until after the election, always, of course, with the intention of subsequently squeezing the States financially, which it has now done. The Government did that, I stress, in spite of an unequivocal promise given by the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick-I am pleased to notice that he is in the chamber and I remind him yet again of the unequivocal promise he made-on 27 April 1976 that payments to the States in real terms would increase in the next three years by more than they had done in the three years of the Labor Government. I have a table which will show just how that promise was not kept.

That unequivocal guarantee from Senator Carrick in April 1976 casts some reflections upon the much less equivocal guarantees allegedly to be given at some time in the future by, as yet, unnamed Government Ministers concerning airlines policy and the two airlines agreement, guarantees which, to my very great surprise, Senator Rae naively accepted last night. Shortly I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows total Commonwealth payments to the States from 1972-73 to 1980-81, the final figure, of course, being an estimate both in current prices and constant prices and as a percentage of Commonwealth taxation. That table clearly shows that during the three years of Labor Government the amounts paid to the States, expressed both as a percentage of total Commonwealth taxation and in constant value dollars, increased very substantially. They then went on a declining trend in both instances-as a percentage of total Commonwealth taxation and in real terms under the Fraser Government-a trend which has continued until 1980-81 and which will intensify in the next financial year because the general purpose payments to the States are to be increased under this Bill by only 9 per cent. The rate of inflation-that is, according to increases in the CPI-for the next financial year is anticipated by almost everyone to be in the vicinity of 11 per cent and wage increases, which are more important to the States than increases in the consumer price index, have increased even more.

The arrangements under the 1975 Act have been described by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, amongst others, as too generous. Frankly, I am inclined to agree with them but that does not exonerate Senator Carrick, Mr Fraser and all of those senior Ministers who, in 1975 and 1976 made irresponsible promises to increase payments to the States above the level prevailing in 1974 and 1975 which they now describe as being too generous. I repeat, anyone who accepts an unequivocal guarantee from a senior Minister of this Government has a penchant for taking a gamble. Anyone who accepts a non-equivocal guarantee to be given at some time in the future by some unnamed Minister is culpably naive.

Regarding the provisions for health services grants to the States, I shall not deal with that matter in detail because it will be dealt with at some subsequent stage by Senator Grimes. I shall make a few general observations. Firstly, these changes will not save Commonwealth revenue. In fact, the net cost to the Commonwealth as a result of these changes will increase by something like $340m. It will not be shown on the Budget Papers as that because the major additional cost incurred by the Commonwealth is, of course, the tax concession. It is more costly to the Commonwealth because it provides hidden subsidies for private health funds, private hospitals and fee for service medicine-primarily general practitioners and hospital and surgery consultations.

There is, in fact, a direct subsidy from the Commonwealth for all medical services covered by the insurance scheme of 30 per cent of the standard fee and a hidden indirect subsidy by way of a taxation concession equal to 32 per cent of the insurance premium. So, in fact, the Commonwealth is paying more than 50 per cent of all those doctors bills which will be covered by these proposed arrangements. This is not free enterprise medicine. This is medicine subsidised by more than 50 per cent from the public purse. Even more obnoxious, of course, is the fact that any citizen taxpayer who declines to join one of the so-called voluntary, private funds will be denied that Commonwealth subsidy, both the direct subsidy and also the taxation concession which is available for private insurance. In other words, what the arrangements do and what they are designed to do is to provide a captive market for the private health funds, to subsidise or guarantee the incomes of members of the Australian Medical Association and, of course, to subsidise and encourage the expansion of the private hospital system at a time when in most States we already have surplus aggregate hospital capacity.

Apart from all the grubby politics, this policy is based on the fiscal deterrent theory-that is, that if people actually have to pay for medical services they will not over-use them and if they do not have to pay for them they will over-use them. The theory, of course, is cancelled by the corollary that goes with it in the policy, that is, private insurance, because once a person is privately insured he does not pay the fee anyway. So there is a fundamental contradiction between the policy and the theory upon which it is based. Even overlooking that basic contradiction, the policy also ignores the fact that demand is determined, for really expensive medical services such as hospitalisation, surgery and sophisticated treatment, not by the patient but by the doctors. As enunciated in its policies, the Government is committed to the protection of the Australian marine environment. The Government has pursued the implementation of this policy on both the national and international fronts by participating in consultations aimed at producing agreed measures for the prevention and control of marine pollution.

The purpose of the Bill which is now before you is to control marine pollution through dumping and incineration, by implementing the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, together with amendments to the convention introduced in 1978 and 1980. The need for a convention to control the dumping of wastes at sea was recognised in 1971 by the first meeting of the preparatory committee for the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment. As a result of support expressed at this meeting the convention was finalised in 1972. It has been in force internationally since 1975, with some 45 countries now being a party to it.

The control of marine pollution through dumping and Australian ratification of the convention has been the subject of detailed discussions with the States and the Northern Territory in various forums, including the Australian Environment Council, the Solicitors-General committee, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Premiers Conference. These detailed discussions have paved the way for the Commonwealth Government to introduce this Bill to control and in some instances prevent, the transport of wastes to sea for the purposes of disposal. This Bill, which has been developed in the spirit of co-operative federalism, takes full account of international, national and State interests. The Bill, which repeals the beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act 1932-1961 will enable Australia to formalise the existing voluntary arrangements dealing with dumping by the establishment of regulatory machinery which will:

Prohibit the dumping of wastes or other matter listed in annex I to the convention, which include organohalogen, mercury and cadmium compounds, plastics, hydrocarbons and high level radioactive waste;

Regulate through the prior issuing of a special permit the dumping of wastes or other matter listed in annex II to the convention, which includes bulky objects, wastes containing significant amounts of heavy metals and low-level radioactive material;
Regulate the dumping of all other wastes or matter through the prior issuing of a general permit;
Ensure formal consideration of all factors listed in annex III to the convention concerning criteria governing the issue of permits;
Ensure the condition of the sea for the purposes of the convention is properly monitored.

The regulatory machinery provided by this Bill will apply to Australian vessels, aircraft or platforms believed to be engaged in dumping and vessels and aircraft loading in Australia or in Australian waters matter which is to be dumped. In line with the 1978 amendment to the convention the Bill also applies to incineration at sea carried out by any vessels in Australian waters, by Australian platforms and by Australian vessels in any part of the sea. The Bill does not apply to the operational discharge of wastes from vessels, aircraft or platforms. This matter is covered by other international conventions many of which have been implemented in Australia.

For the purposes of this Bill, Australian waters is defined to include the territorial sea of Australia and the external territories and any sea that is on the landward side of the territorial sea, other than any part of the sea that is within the limits of a State or the Northern Territory. This is to ensure that a legal vacuum does not occur for the control of dumping inside the territorial sea of Australia. The definition of Australian waters also includes an area of the sea on the seaward side of the territorial sea of Australia or the territorial sea of an external territory that is declared to be Australian waters by the regulations. This provision will allow the Government to move swiftly to extend the jurisdiction of the Bill to take account of developments in the International Control of Marine Pollution. Clause 9 of the Bill gives effect to the agreement reached at the June 1980 Premiers Conference. It makes provision for the States and the Northern Territory to control dumping in the coastal waters under their own legislation implementing the provisions of the dumping convention, if they so desire. Naturally it will be necessary to establish consultative arrangements between the Commonwealth, States and the Northern Territory to consider the environmental consequences of proposed dumping operations, wherever they might occur.

Clauses 13 and 14 set out the penalties for an offence for dumping, loading or incinerating of wastes or other matter otherwise than in accordance with a permit. As set out in clause 17 of the Bill, in the case where the Commonwealth has incurred expenses or other liabilities in repairing or remedying any condition resulting from dumping in contravention of the Bill, the person convicted of the offence is liable for expenses.

In keeping with Australia's participation in the development and implementation of international conventions the enactment of this Bill will enable Australia to accede to the dumping convention. The legislation, by opening the way for Australia to become party to the convention will formalise our own national arrangements to control marine pollution through dumping as agreed between the Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory as part of the off-shore settlement. In addition, Australia's international standing with regard to proposals by other countries to dispose of wastes by dumping at sea will be strengthened. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision, announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 30 April 1981, that concurrently with the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal, a Petroleum Product Pricing Authority would be established for the maintenance of the Government's petroleum product pricing policy. The Petroleum Product Pricing Authority proposed by this Bill will take over from the PJT the specific responsibility for price surveillance of the petroleum products industry. The Authority will have substantially fewer staff than the PJT but will have powers similar to those that the PJT now has in relation to the prices of petroleum products. Surveillance of the prices of the industry will extend only to defined petroleum products and to services related to the production or supply of such products.

The Bill provides for the creation of an office of Commissioner for Petroleum Products Pricing. The Commissioner can also hold simultaneously, if necessary, the office of full time member of the Temporary Assistance Authority. Provision is also made for the appointment of Associate Commissioners for the purposes of particular inquiries. The Minister's direction or approval will be required before an inquiry can be conducted by the Authority. Inquiries by the Authority will not necessarily be confined to the justification of particular prices. It will also be able to undertake inquiries of a more general nature relating to the prices of petroleum products or associated services.

The companies which will be required to notify the Authority of proposed price increases are those companies which are declared by the Minister by notice published in the Gazette. Where a proposed increase is to be subjected to an inquiry, the Authority will be able to withhold the increase or grant an interim increase pending the outcome of the inquiry. The Minister will have the power to give directions to the Authority on matters which should be given special consideration. Confidentiality of material submitted by companies will be adequately protected under the provisions of clauses 26 and 37 of the Bill.

The Bill provides for appropriate surveillance of petroleum product prices, bearing in mind that these prices have been affected sharply in recent years by world-wide increases in crude oil prices. The legislation has been framed to ensure that the activities of the Authority have due regard to the interest of the industry and those of the community as a whole. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make a brief statement in relation to the inquiry of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations into the Australian Dairy Corporation. In view of the time, I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard. It is an approved statement of a bipartisan Committee. I will ensure that copies of it are available and distributed to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Two submissions to the inquiry, from the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation and the New South Wales Dairy Farmers Association, have been publicly released without the authorisation of the Committee. Apparently the submissions were released by the organisations themselves. Neither organisation sought the Committee's approval to release the submissions. As honourable senators will be aware, the publication of these documents is a prima facie breach of Standing Order 308.

The Committee accepts the explanation of the organisations that they were unaware of the provisions of the Standing Order when they released their submissions and will take no action other than to draw the attention of the organisations to the existence of the Standing Order.

At a meeting on Wednesday last the Committee formally decided to authorise the public release of the submissions. This decision was taken in order to overcome the problem of the breach and to avoid any suggestion that the Committee was attempting to inhibit public debate on the inquiry or to prevent some interested parties' views, especially those critical of the Committee's proceedings, from being aired.

One effect of Standing Order 308 is to protect witnesses who wish their submissions to remain confidential to the Committee against their unauthorised release. The Standing Order also is in line with common Committee practice whereby submissions are not released until witnesses appear at a public hearing after which the submissions are incorporated in a Hansard transcript of the evidence.

The two organisations concerned in this case were happy to release their submissions and therefore did not desire the protection afforded by Standing Order 308. So far as the practice of this Committee is concerned we have decided that in such cases, where the organisation providing a submission in happy for it to be released, and where further evidence is unlikely to be taken at a public hearing, the submission will be publicly released as soon as it is received, unless there are strong reasons for the contrary. For example, in the past, Senate committees have not released submissions because they appeared to be solely designed to use the cloak of parliamentary privilege in order to make defamatory statements.

I would also like to take the opportunity, Mr President, to comment on some other actions of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. The Committee noted reported comments made in Melbourne last week by the President of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, Mr J. F. Bennett. He is reported to have said that the ADFF had not been asked to make a submission on the inquiry into the Australian Dairy Corporation and its associated overseas companies until after the public hearings had finished and the first draft of the report had been written.
Mr President, the facts of the matter are:

The Committee advertised in the national Press in early March 1980 seeking submissions on its general terms of reference governing the oversight of statutory authorities within which the inquiry on the ADC is being conducted. The ADFF did not make a submission as a result of this advertisement.
The Committee commenced correspondence specifically with the ADFF in September 1980 to obtain preliminary background information on the ADC inquiry.

The Committee formally invited a submission from the ADFF on 24 March 1981. Public hearings had not closed at that stage. The most recent public hearing was held on 20 May 1981. The Committee will hold further hearings if necessary.
The first draft of the report had not been commenced on 24 March 1981.

The ADFF was well aware of the existence of the inquiry from its commencement on 20 November 1980. The Committee had been in constant contact with the ADC, which numbers among its members the President and Deputy President of the ADFF. On 7 December 1980 the Deputy Chairman of the ADFF was approached to give evidence on the inquiry and he appeared at a public hearing on 12 February 1981.

The ADFF did not make any request to appear before the Committee, to make a submission to the Committee or to have an observer at the public hearings of the Committee until after the Committee's letter of 24 March 1981.
